div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: The scene is a drawing-room , prettily but somewhat showily decorated . The walls are papered with a design representing large clusters of white and purple lilac . The furniture is covered with a chintz of similar pattern , and the curtains , carpet , and lamp-shades correspond .

In the wall facing the spectator are two windows , and midway between the windows there is the entrance to a conservatory . The conservatory , which is seen beyond , is of the kind that is built out over the portico of a front-door , and is plentifully stocked with flowers and hung with a velarium and green sun-blinds . In the right-hand wall there is another window and , nearer the spectator , a console-table supporting a high mirror ; and in the wall on the left , opposite the console-table , there is a double-door opening into the room , the further half of which only is used .

In the entrance to the conservatory , to the right , there is a low , oblong tea-table at which are placed three small chairs ; and near-by , on the left , are a grand-piano and a music-stool . Against the piano there is a settee , and on the extreme left , below the door , there is an arm-chair with a little round table beside it . At the right-hand window in the wall at the back is another settee , and facing this window and settee there is a smaller arm-chair .

Not far from the fire-place there is a writing-table with a telephone-instrument upon it . A chair stands at the writing-table , its back to the window in the wall on the right ; and in front of the table , opposing the settee by the piano , there is a third settee . On the left of this settee , almost in the middle of the room , is an arm-chair ; and closer to the settee , on its right , are two more arm-chairs . Other articles of furniture — a cabinet , “ occasional ” chairs , etc ., etc .— occupy spaces against the walls .

On the piano , on the console-table and cabinet , on the settee at the back , on the round table , and upon the floor , stand huge baskets of flowers , and other handsome floral devices in various forms , with cards attached to them ; and lying higgledy-piggledy upon the writing-table are a heap of small packages , several little cases containing jewellery , and a litter of paper and string . The packages and the cases of jewellery are also accompanied by cards or letters .
A fierce sunlight streams down upon the velarium , and through the green blinds , in the conservatory .

div.stage: Note : Throughout , “ right ” and “ left ” are the spectators ’ right and left , not the actor 's .

LORD FARNCOMBE , his gloves in his hand , is seated in the arm-chair in the middle of the room . He is a simple-mannered , immaculately dressed young man in his early twenties , his bearing and appearance suggesting the soldier . He rises expectantly as GLADYS , a flashy parlourmaid in a uniform , shows in LIONEL ROPER , a middle-aged individual of the type of the second-class City man .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE .Hul-lo ! I 'm in luck ! Just the chap I 'm hunting for .Shaking hands with FARNCOMBE .How d'ye do , Lord Farncombe ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: How are you , Roper ?

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: To ROPER , languidly .I 'll tell Mrs. Upjohn you 're here .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Ta .GLADYS withdraws .Phew , it 's hot !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Miss Parradell 's out .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Taking off his gloves .She wo n't be long , I dare say .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I 've brought her a few flowers .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Have you ? I 've sent her a trifle of jewellery .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Glancing at the writing-table .She seems to have received a lot of jewellery .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Bustling across to the table .By Jove , does n't she ! Ah , there 's my brooch !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Modestly .I did n't consider I 'd a right to offer her anything but flowers , on so slight an acquaintance .

lg.l: Exactly ; but I 'm an old friend , you know .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Smiling .I hope so .

lg.stage: Approaching FARNCOMBE and taking him by the lapel of his coat .
lg.l: What I want to say to you is , doing anything to-night ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I — I shall be at the theatre .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Oh , we shall all be at the theatre , to shout Many Happy Returns . Later , I mean .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Nothing that I can n't get out of .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Good . Look here . Smythe is giving her a bit of supper in the foyer after the show , a dance on the stage to follow . About five-and-twenty people . ‘ Ull you come ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: If Mr. Smythe is kind enough to ask me ——

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: He does ask you , through me . He 's left all the arrangements to me and Morrie Cooling . Carlton never did anything in his life ; I egged him on to this . I 've been sweating at it since eleven o'clock this morning . Have n't been near the City ; not near it . Well ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: His eyes glowing .I shall be delighted .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Splendid . Been trying to get on to you all day . I 've called twice at your club and at St. James 's Place .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Sorry you 've had so much trouble .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Dropping on to the settee in front of the writing-table and wiping his brow .There 'll be the Baron , Sam de Castro , Bertie Fulkerson , Stew Heneage , Jerry Grimwood , Dwarf Kennedy , Colonel and Mrs. Stidulph — Dolly Ensor that was — and ourselves , besides Cooling and Vincent Bland and the pick o ’ the Company . Catani does the food and drink . I do n't believe I 've forgotten a single thing .With a change of tone , pointing to the arm-chair in the middle of the room .Sit down a minute .FARNCOMBE sits and ROPER edges nearer to him .Are you going to wait to see Lily this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I — I should like to .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Because if Jeyes should happen to drop in while you 're here ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Captain Jeyes ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Nicko Jeyes — or if you knock up against him to-night at the theatre — mum about this .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: About the supper ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Nodding .Um . We do n't want Nicko Jeyes ; we simply do n't want him . And if he heard that you and some of the boys are coming , he might wonder why he is n't included .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: He strikes me as being rather a surly , ill-conditioned person .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: A regular loafer .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: He appears to live at Catani 's . I never go there without meeting him .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Exactly . Catani 's and a top , back bedroom in Jermyn Street , and hanging about the Pandora ; that 's Nicko Jeyes 's life .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: He 's an old friend of Mrs. Upjohn 's and Miss Parradell 's too , is n't he ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Evasively .Known ‘ em some time . That 's it ; Lily 's so faithful to her old friends .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Smiling .You ought n't to complain of that .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Oh , but I 'm a real friend . I 've always been a patron of the musical drama — it 's my fad ; and I 've kept an eye on Lily from the moment she sprang into prominence —singing“ Mind the paint ! Mind the paint ! ” — looked after her like a father . Uncle Lal she calls me .Reassuringly .I 'm a married man , you know ;FARNCOMBE nodsbut the wife has plenty to occupy her with the kids and she leaves the drama to me . She prefers Bexhill .Leaning forward and speaking with great earnestness .Farncombe , what a charming creature !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Innocently .Mrs. Roper ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: No , no , no ; Lily .Hastily .Oh , and so 's my missus , for that matter , when she chooses . But Lily Upjohn ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: In a low voice .Beautiful ; perfectly beautiful .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Yes , and as good as she 's beautiful ; you take it from me .With a wave of the hand .Well , if you see Jeyes , you wo n't ——?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Not a word .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Rising and walking away to the left .I 've warned the others .Returning to FARNCOMBE who has also risen .By-the-bye , if Lily should mention the supper in the course of conversation , remember , she 's not in the conspiracy .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Conspiracy ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To shunt Nicko . We 're letting her think there are to be no outsiders .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Becoming slightly puzzled by ROPER 'S manner .Why , would she very much like Captain Jeyes to be asked ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Rather impatiently .Have n't I told you , once you 're a friend of Lil 's ——!Looking towards the door .Is this Ma ?MRS. UPJOHN enters .Hul-lo , Ma !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: A podgy little , gaily dressed woman of five-and-fifty with a stupid , good-humoured face .‘ Ullo , Uncle !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Lord Farncombe ——

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Advancing and shaking hands with FARNCOMBE .Glad to see you ‘ ere again . You ‘ ave been before , ‘ ave n't you ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Last week .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Of course ; you came with Mr. Bertie Fulkerson . But somebody or other 's always poppin ’ in .Pleasantly .Lil sees too many , I say . It 's tirin ’ for ‘ er . Wo n't you set ?

lg.l: Lord Farncombe 's brought Lily some flowers , Ma .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Who , after waiting for MRS. UPJOHN to settle herself upon the settee in front of the writing-table , sits in the chair at the end of the settee — pointing to a large basket of flowers .On the piano .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Barely glancing at the flowers .‘ Ow kind of ‘ im ! Sech a waste o ’ money too ! They do go off so quick .

lg.stage: Reading the cards attached to the various floral gifts .

lg.l: She 's settin ’ to a risin ’ young artist in Fitzroy Street — Claude
Morgan . She wo n't be ‘ ome till past five . So tirin ’ for ‘ er .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Never heard of Morgan .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: No , nor anybody else . That 's what I tell ‘ er . Why waste your time givin ’ settin 's to a risin ’ young artist when the big men ‘ ud go down on their ‘ ands and knees to do you ? But that 's Lil all over . She 's the best-natured girl in the world , and so she gets imposed on all round .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Gallantly .I prophesy that Mr. Morgan 's picture of Miss Parradell wo n't have dried before he 's quite famous .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Turning a pair of dull eyes full upon him .‘ Ow do you mean ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Disconcerted .Er — I mean —

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Why wo n't it ‘ ave dried ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I mean he will have become celebrated before it has dried .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ Is pictures never do dry , you mean ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: No , no , Ma !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ Owever , it does n't matter . ‘ E is n't even goin ’ to put ‘ er name to it .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: You may well ask . ‘ E 's bent on callin ’ it “ The ‘ Mind the Paint ’ Girl . ”

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: What 's wrong with that ? Everybody 'll recognise who that is .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Unconvinced .‘ Er name 's printed on all ‘ er photos .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: The first time I had the pleasure of seeing your daughter on the stage , Mrs. Upjohn , a man next to me said , “ Here comes the ‘ Mind the Paint ’ girl . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Cheering up .Oh , well , p'r ' aps young Morgan knows ‘ is own business best . Let 's ‘ ope so , at any rate .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: By the tea-table , beckoning to FARNCOMBE .Farncombe ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: To ROPER .Eh ?To MRS. UPJOHN , rising .Excuse me .

div.stage: FARNCOMBE joins ROPER , whereupon MRS. UPJOHN goes to the writing-table and , seating herself there , examines the jewellery delightedly .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE , in a whisper .Do me a favour .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Looking at his watch .It 's only half-past four . Take a turn round the Square . I 've some business to talk over with the old lady .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Nodding to ROPER and then coming forward and addressing MRS. UPJOHN .I — er — I think I 'll go for a little walk and come back later on , if I may .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Contentedly .Oh , jest as you like .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Moving towards the door .In about a quarter-of-an-hour .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: If we do n't see you again , I 'll tell Lil you 've been ‘ ere .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: At the door .Oh , but you will ; you will see me again .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Well , please yourself and you please your dearest friend , as Lil 's dad used to say .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Thank you — thank you very much .

div.stage: He disappears , closing the door after him .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: To ROPER , looking up .I b'lieve you gave that young man the ‘ int to go , Uncle .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: I did ; told him I wanted to talk business with you .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Business ?Resuming her inspection of the trinkets .This is a ‘ andsome thing Mr. Grimwood 's sent ‘ er .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: His hands in his trouser-pockets , contemplating MRS. UPJOHN desperately .Upon my soul , Ma , you 're a champion !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Now wot ‘ ave I done !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Well , you might spread yourself a little over young Farncombe .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Spread myself ! Why should I ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Lord Farncombe !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: I treat ‘ em all alike ; so does Lil . ‘ E 's not the first title we 've ‘ ad ‘ ere , not by a dozen .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: No , but damn it all —! I beg your pardon ——

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Beaming .So you ought — swearin ’ like a trooper .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: This chap 's in love with her .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Oh , they 're all in love with ‘ er ; or ‘ ave been , one time or another .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Yes , but they 're not all Farncombes and they 're not all marrying men . I 'm prepared to bet my boots that if Lil and young Farncombe could be thrown together ——!Sitting on the settee in front of the writing-table as MRS. UPJOHN rises and comes forward .Here ! Do talk it over .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Placidly .Where 's the use o ’ talkin ’ it over ? It 's wastin ’ one 's breath .Moving to the settee by the piano .My Lil does n't want to marry — any'ow not yet awhile ; she 's ‘ appy and contented as she is .Sitting and smoothing out her skirt .When she does , I s'pose it 'll be the Captain .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Between his teeth .The Captain !Quietly .Ma , the day Lil marries Nicko Jeyes , you and she 'll see the last o ’ me .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Oh , do n't say that , Uncle .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: I do say it . The disappointment ‘ ud be more than I could stand . Selfish , designing beggar !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Now , no low abuse .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: A fellow who gets on the soft side of Lil before she 's out of her teens — before she 's made any position to speak of ; and when she has made a position , and he 's practically on his uppers , sticks to her like a limpet !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: She sticks to ‘ im , too . It meant a deal to Lil in ‘ er ‘ umble days , reck'lect — receivin ’ attentions from a gentleman in the army . She does n't forget that .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Jumping up and walking about .It 's cruel ; that 's what it is — it 's cruel . Here 's Gwennie Harker and Maidie Trevail both married to peers ’ sons , and Eva Shafto to a baronet — all of ‘ em Pandora girls ; and Lil — she 's left high and dry , engaged to a nobody ! It 's cruel !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: She 's not ackshally engaged .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Ho , ho !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: The ideer was , when ‘ e shirked goin ’ to India an ’ gave up soldierin ’ , so as to be near ‘ er , that ‘ e should get something to do in London ; then they were to be engaged .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Sarcastically .Oh , to be just , I admit he 's in no hurry . He 's been a whole year looking for something to do in London — looking for it at Catani 's and at the Pandora bars !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ E ‘ as to be on the spot at night , to bring Lil ‘ ome after ‘ er work .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Exactly ! And when a decent , eligible young chap comes along , and means business , he 's choked off by finding Nicko Jeyes in possession .Stopping before MRS. UPJOHN .But , I say !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Wot ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Farncombe has n't tumbled to it yet .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Indifferently .‘ As n't ‘ e ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Bertie Fulkerson 's held his tongue about it ; so have the other boys who 're friends of Farncombe 's . They see he 's hard hit .Enthusiastically .Oh , they 're good boys ; they 're good , loyal boys ! There 's not one of them who would n't throw up his hat if Nicko got the chuck .Suddenly .Ma !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Startled .Hey ?

lg.l: This little spree to-night at the theatre —
Lil thinks it 's to be merely among the members of the Company .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Ai n't it ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Sitting beside her .You keep quiet , now . No , it is n't .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: The boys — and Farncombe .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Disturbed .Gracious ! There 'll be an awful fuss with the Captain to-morrer .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Snapping his fingers .Pishhh !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Rising and walking away to the right .‘ E 's so ‘ orribly jealous . When Lil tells ‘ im ‘ oo was at the party , there 'll be a frightful kick-up !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Falling into despondency .Oh , I dare say I 'm a fool for my pains , Ma . Nothing 'll come of it .Rising and pacing the room again .Farncombe 's as shy as a school-girl ; he 'd be on a desert island with a pretty woman for a month without squeezing her hand .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: In an altered tone .Uncle .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Hullo !

lg.l: I should n't raise any objection , bear in mind , if
Lil could be weaned away from the Captain and took a fancy to young

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Objection !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Sitting on the settee in front of the writing-table .All said an ’ done , to be Lady F ., with no need to work if you 're not disposed to , is better than bein ’ Mrs. Captain Jeyes an ’ ‘ avin ’ to linger on the stage , p'r ' aps , till you drop , to ‘ elp keep the pot a ’ boilin ’ .Opening her eyes widely .Lady F .!

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Coming to her .And Countess of Godalming when his father dies .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: I s'pose there 'd be any amount of unpleasantness with the fam'ly ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Disdainfully .The family !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: There 's generally a rumpus in sech cases .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Why , Ma , these tiptop families ought to feel jolly grateful that we 're mixing the breed for them a bit . Look at the two lads who 've married Gwennie Harker and Maidie Trevail — Kinterton and Glenroy ; and Fawcus — Sir George Fawcus — Eva Shafto 's husband ; they have n't a chin or a forehead between ‘ em , and their chests are as narrow as a ten-inch plank .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Quite true .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Farncombe himself , he 's inclined to be weedy . I maintain it 's a grand thing for our English nobs that their slips of sons have taken to marrying young women of the stamp of Maidie Trevail and Gwennie Harker — or Lil ; keen-witted young women full of the joy of life , with strong frames , beautiful hair and fine eyes , and healthy pink gums and big white teeth . Sneer at the Pandora girls ! Great Scot , it 's my belief that the Pandora girls 'll be the salvation of the aristocracy in this country in the long run !

div.stage: CAPTAIN NICHOLAS JEYES lounges in . He is a man of about five-and-thirty , already slightly grey-haired , who has gone to seed . ROPER sits in the chair in the middle of the room rather guiltily and MRS. UPJOHN puts on a propitiatory grin .

lg.stage: Nodding to MRS. UPJOHN and ROPER as he closes the door .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Ah , Captain !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Hullo , Nicko !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Advancing .Lily not in ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: No ; she 's in Fitzroy Street , settin ’ to Morgan .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Frowning .Why did n't she ask me to go with her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Dun'no , I 'm sure . She 's took Miss Birch .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: With a grunt .Oh ?Looking round .Flowers .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ Eaps of ‘ em , ai n't there ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Jerking his head towards the writing-table .Yes , and some nice presents over here .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: She 's beat ‘ er record this year , Lil ‘ as , out an ’ out .

div.stage: JEYES goes to the writing-table and ROPER and MRS. UPJOHN rise and wander away , the former to the conservatory , the latter to the settee by the piano .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Scowling at the presents .Very nice .Picking up a case of jewellery .Ve-ry nice .Throwing the case down angrily .Confound ‘ em , what the devil do they take her for !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: At the entrance to the conservatory .I may remark that one of those gifts is from me , Jeyes .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Oh , I 'm not alluding to you .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Stiffly .Much obliged .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Coming forward and addressing MRS. UPJOHN .I 've called in to ask Lily whether she 'll come out to supper with me to-night , to Catani 's , to celebrate her birthday . Luigi 's decorating a table for me specially . Mr. and Mrs. Linthorne 'll come , and Jack Wethered .To ROPER .Are you free , Roper ?MRS. UPJOHN sits uneasily on the settee by the piano and ROPER finds some object to interest him near the tea-table .I suppose it 's no good asking you , Mrs. Upjohn ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: N-n-o , thank you , Captain , and I — I 'm afraid ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Afraid ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: I 'm afraid Lil can n't manage it either .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: I — I 'm surprised she did n't mention it to you ‘ erself when you brought ‘ er ‘ ome last night .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Mention what ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: They 're givin ’ ‘ er a supper to-night at the theatre .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: The theatre ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Advancing .Yes , Carlton 's standing a little spread in the foyer , in honour of the occasion .Sitting at the tea-table .Quite right too ; she 's his best asset , and chance it .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: When was it fixed up ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Late last night .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: The fact is , Lily and I had a slight tiff coming home last night .Sitting on the settee in front of the writing-table .Ha ! I suppose she kept it from me to pay me out .Sharply .Who 's invited ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Er — only the principal members of the Company , I understand .

lg.stage: Moistening her lips with her tongue .
lg.l: Yes , only the members of the

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: With Morrie Cooling and Vincent Bland thrown in .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Looking at ROPER .You seem to know a lot about it , Roper .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: I was behind when Morrie was going round to the dressing-rooms .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: To ROPER , suspiciously .Are you asked ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Taken aback .E — eh ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Are you asked ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: With an attempt at airiness .Oh , yes , they 've dragged me into it .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Since when have you been a member of the Company ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: No , but — dash it , I 've done business for Carlton in the City for twenty years or more ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: That does n't make you one .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: And I 'm an old friend of Lil 's .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Not older than I .Violently .Why the blazes does n't Smythe invite me ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Extending his arms .My dear Nicko , I 'm not giving the party . Really , you do jump down a man 's throat ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Sorry , sorry , sorry .Leaning back and thrusting his hands into his pocket .Well , I 'll put Jack and the Linthornes off . They do n't want to sup with me ; I should n't amuse ‘ em .Gazing at the carpet .Her birthday , though ! It 'll be the first time I shall have been out of that for — how many years ?— six years . I ——Raising his head , he detects MRS. UPJOHN and ROPER eyeing each other uncomfortably .Anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: T-t-the matter ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Taking his hands from his pockets and sitting upright .Any game on ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Game ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: At my expense ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: I dun'no wot you 're drivin ’ at , Captain .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Harshly .How long 's Lily sitting this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Till five .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Looking at his watch .What 's Morgan 's number in Fitzroy Street ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Sixty .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Rising .I 'll fetch her .

div.stage: As he makes a movement towards the door , it is thrown open and LILY PARRADELL enters with a rush — an entrancing vision of youth , grace , and beauty . She is followed by JIMMIE BIRCH , a petite , bright-eyed girl in an extremely chic costume .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Tearing off her gloves as she enters .Wh-e-e-w ! I 'm dead !Giving her hand to JEYES carelessly .Ah , Nicko !To MRS. UPJOHN .I could n't stand the heat in the studio any longer , mother .Finding ROPER beside her , she offers her cheek to him and he kisses it .Mon Oncle !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Closing the door .That young man Morgan ought to paint the infernal regions .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Taking her scarf from her shoulder .He might finish with the angels first , though .To JEYES , softly , as ROPER turns to shake hands with JIMMIE .You in a better temper to-day ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: In her ear .You drove me wild last night .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Making a face at him .Served you right .Passing him .For God 's sake , let me lie down .She throws herself upon the settee in front of the writing-table , and JEYES moves away as MRS. UPJOHN and ROPER go to her .Do n't come near me . Give me my fan . Jimmie , where 's my fan ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Oh , I 've left it in Fitzroy Street !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Beast !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Hurrying to the writing-table .There 's one ‘ ere , among your presents .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Unpinning her hat .Uncle Lal , what an adorable ring that is you 've sent me !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Taking the fan from MRS. UPJOHN .Ring ! A brooch !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Somebody 's sent me a ring .

lg.stage: Sitting in the chair at the end of the settee by the writing-table .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Of course ! One of them 's from Nicko !To JEYES .Did you get my sweet telegram , Nicko ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Who has greeted JIMMIE and is now seated in the chair on the extreme left — sulkily .I had your telegram , but it 's a pendant I sent you .

lg.stage: Sitting upon the settee by the piano and pulling off her gloves .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: You shut up , Jimmie .Snatching the fan from ROPER .How on earth am I to remember !Fanning herself .Who 's given me this pretty thing ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Mr. Monty Levine .

lg.l: Bless him ! He 's a dear little man , though he does bite his nails .
lg.stage: GLADYS appears with VINCENT BLAND , who saunters in after her . Seeing LILY , GLADYS advances to her .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: A thin , delicate looking man of eight-and-thirty , not over smartly dressed , wearing an eye-glass — nodding to LILY casually .You need n't have cut me , almost on your door-step .To JIMMIE and JEYES .H'lo , Jimmie ! H'lo , Nicko !

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: Viewing LILY with an elevation of the brows .Oh , are you home ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Returning GLADYS 'S stare .Apparently .

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: I 'll whistle up to Maud .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Do n't , if it 's too severe a strain on you .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: To GLADYS , as the girl moves to the door .Gladys , we 'll ‘ ave tea .

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: At the door .You can n't till it 's ready .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Calmly .Cheek !

div.stage: GLADYS retires .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Who has strolled across to LILY , indolently .Why do you retain the services of that tousled-headed hussy ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With conviction .Oh , she 's a little under the weather , but she 's a perfect servant .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: To MRS. UPJOHN .Ma , you look blooming .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Wish I could return the compliment , Mr . Bland .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: To ROPER , who is wearing a waistcoat of rather a pronounced pattern .Congratulations on your waistcoat , Lal .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Joining JIMMIE , annoyed .Now , no personalities .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Giving BLAND her hand .Vincent , yours is one of the loveliest presents I 've had to-day . Remerciement ! How 's that for a French accent ?

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Dropping his eyeglass .You cat !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Why ——?

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: You know I 've given you nothing , not even a penny nosegay .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: The funds are too low .Replacing his eyeglass .I did go so far as to price a bangle at Sellby 's , but that was before a certain event yesterday .

lg.l: What horses did you back , Vincent ? I won a fiver , through Jerry

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To BLAND .You are a patent ass . Why do n't you leave betting alone ?

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: To ROPER , flaring up .Why do n't you leave your City muck alone ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Putting her feet to the floor , imperiously .That 'll do . Be quiet , you two ! I wo n't have any wrangling in my house . Run away and play , all of you . I want to speak to Vincent for a minute privately .With a gesture .Uncle Lal — Jimmie — Nicko —To MRS. UPJOHN .Scoot , mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Oh , dear , wot a child !

div.stage: ROPER , JIMMIE , JEYES , and MRS. UPJOHN move away and LILY beckons to BLAND .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Vin .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Close to her , with a wry face .Mercy !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a low voice .You 've broken your word to me , then ?Through her teeth .Those damned horses !

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Cooling had a tip from the stable ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Cooling ! Morrie Cooling has no children ; only a fat wife . You 've a darling little wife and three kiddies . How much did you drop yesterday ?

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Sha n't say .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rising and touching his arm .Oh , Vincent !

div.stage: She looks round , to assure herself that she is unobserved . MRS. UPJOHN and ROPER are seated at the tea-table with their heads together , talking ; JIMMIE is at the piano , fingering out a piece of music ; JEYES is half hidden in the arm-chair facing the settee at the back . LILY tiptoes to the writing-table and seats herself there as GLADYS reappears showing in the BARON VON RETTENMAYER .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: A tall , fair young man of three-and-thirty , speaking in thick , guttural tones — advancing to LILY .Aha , goddess !Gladys withdraws .Many habby returns of the day !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: H'sh ! I 'm busy for a moment , Baron .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: To LILY — shaking hands with BLAND .A thousand bardons .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Talk to mother and Jimmie .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: With bleasure .Going to MRS. UPJOHN and ROPER and shaking hands with them .How are you , my dear Ma ? How are you , Jimmie ?Waving a hand to ROPER and JEYES .My dear Rober ! My dear Neegolas !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To VON RETTENMAYER , mimicking him .Rober ! Neegolas ! Why do n't they provide you with throat lozenges at the Embassy , Baron ?

div.stage: VON RETTENMAYER laughs . LILY has quickly opened a drawer in the writing-table and produced a cheque-book . After another glance over her shoulder , she sweeps the presents aside and writes . Then she replaces the cheque-book , rises , and returns to BLAND . Again there is a loud guffaw from VON RETTENMAYER in response to some sally of JIMMIE 'S .

lg.stage: To BLAND , folding a cheque and slipping it into his hand .
lg.l: Promise — promise you wo n't make another bet .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Unfolding the cheque .Your cheque ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Hastily .Put it in your pocket .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: A blank one .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a whisper .Do n't fill it in for more than you can help . I 'm not over flush .

div.stage: He deliberately tears the cheque into four pieces and , looking at her steadily , puts them into his waistcoat-pocket .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: As he does so .I 'll keep those , Lil , for as long as I keep anything .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Hotly .You fool , Vincent !

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: My dear , as if ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Such ridiculous pride !Stamping her foot .Lord , what I owe to you !

div.stage: GLADYS enters with SAM DE CASTRO . GLADYS is carrying a lace-edged table-cloth which , assisted by MRS. UPJOHN , she proceeds to lay upon the tea-table .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Moving away to join the others — to DE CASTRO .Ha , Sam !

lg.stage: A stout , coarse , but genial-looking gentleman of forty , of marked Jewish appearance , speaking with a lisp — shaking hands with LILY .
lg.l: How are you to-day , Lil ? Many happy returnth , wunth more .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Thanks , dear old boy .Sitting on the settee in front of the writing-table .Did I send you a wire this morning ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Not you ; not a thix-pen'north .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I ought to have done so , to acknowledge your — what was it ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: A ring — diamondth and thapphires .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Ah , yes ; beautiful .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: It ith rather a nithe ring .Lowering his voice .But I thay .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Mind you do n't go and tell Gabth , on any account .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With a great assumption of ignorance , raising her eyebrows .Gabs ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Gabrielle — Mith Kato .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Why should n't I ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Nonsenth ; you know very well .Urgently .You wo n't , will you ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Shrugging her shoulders .I wo n't if I remember not to .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Alarmed .Ah , now , do n't be thtupid ! Whath the good o ’ making mithchief !LILY shows him the tip of her tongue .Oh , Lil !GLADYS goes out .Lil ——!

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Leaving the group at the back and putting an arm round DE CASTRO 'S shoulder .My dear friend Zam !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: How are you , Baron ?Going to MRS. UPJOHN .Afthernoon , Ma !Nodding to JIMMIE and ROPER .Afthernoon , everybody !Shaking hands with JEYES , who has risen and now joins the group .How are you , Nicko ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Giving her hand to VON RETTENMAYER .Excuse me for cutting you short when you came in . Thanks for your splendid present . I did send you a wire , did n't I ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Kissing her hand and bowing over it .I shall breserve it , with a few oder souvenirs , till the end of my life .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Withdrawing her hand and blowing the compliment away .Phew ! Lal , lal , lal , la !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: In an altered tone , after a cautious look round .Goddess .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Anxiously .My drifling liddle offering — I endreat you not to mention it to Enid .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Laughing heartily .Ha , ha , ha , ha ! Another of you !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: The gharming Miss Mongreiff .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Seriously .Baron , I wish you boys would n't make me presents and then ask me to keep them a secret from the other girls .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: And I — I wish it were not nezezzary . But , goddess , you are alzo a young lady of the world — you know what women are .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: H 'm ! I know what you men are .

div.stage: MAUD , a buxom young woman with a good-tempered face , dressed as a lady'shYpppHeNmaid , enters quickly , tying her apron , and runs to LILY . JEYES comes to the further side of the writing-table and VON RETTENMAYER now joins him there . JIMMIE BIRCH also comes forward , accompanied by DE CASTRO .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: To LILY .Here , give me your things .LILY tosses her hat , scarf , and gloves to MAUD .I was in my room , having a lie down . Is my hair untidy ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I 've never seen it anything else .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: Merrily .Ha , ha , ha !To JIMMIE and DE CASTRO .Afternoon , Miss Jimmie . Afternoon , Mr. de Castro .To LILY .Now , do n't let them all tire you to death , there 's a pet .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh , clear out .As MAUD is departing .Hi !Rising and kicking off her shoes and sending them in MAUD 'S direction .Fetch me a pair of slippers .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: Picking up the shoes and chuckling .He , he , he !

div.stage: When MAUD reaches the door , which she has left open , GLADYS appears with the tea-tray and with FARNCOMBE at her heels .

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: To MAUD , in a low voice , witheringly .Oh , you 're doing something , are you ?

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: In the same tone , passing GLADYS .Yes , setting you an example , my girl .Encountering FARNCOMBE .Beg pardon .

div.stage: MAUD withdraws , closing the door , and FARNCOMBE stands looking at LILY , who is talking to JIMMIE . GLADYS carries the tray to the tea-table .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Become aware of FARNCOMBE 'S presence and nodding to him .How d'ye do ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Moving a step or two towards her .I — I 've been here before this afternoon . I ventured to bring you some flowers .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Going to him and shaking hands with him formally .Nobody told me . Awfully kind of you . Where have they put them ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Lifting his basket of flowers from off the piano and showing it to her .Here .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Pretty .Pulling out a carnation .Stick it up there again .He replaces the basket .You 're Lord Farncombe , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With a glance at the others .Know anybody here ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Looking round the room .Nearly everybody , I fancy .He advances to VON RETTENMAYER , who comes to meet him . LILY sits upon the settee by the piano and fastens the carnation in her dress . GLADYS goes out .Karl ——!

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: My dear Eddie !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Bowing to DE CASTRO , who is now seated beside JIMMIE on the settee in front of the writing-table .How are you , Mr. de Castro ?To JEYES , who is standing by the chair at the writing-table gnawing his moustache and watching LILY and FARNCOMBE sourly .How are you , Captain Jeyes ?Turning to BLAND .How are you , Mr . Bland ?To LILY .I 've been talking to Mrs. Upjohn and Mr. Roper already .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Looking across to JIMMIE .Miss Birch — Lord Farncombe .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Nodding to FARNCOMBE .How d'ye do ?

lg.stage: Going to JIMMIE and shaking hands with her .
lg.l: I — I need n't say that
I am one of Miss Birch 's warmest — most profound ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Smiling at him .That 's all right ; do n't you bother about that .

div.stage: MAUD returns , carrying a pair of silken slippers . VON RETTENMAYER , who has come to LILY , makes a dart at the slippers and takes them from MAUD .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Aha ! Permid me .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: Now , Baron ——!Slapping his arm .Ha , ha , ha ——!

div.stage: He pushes MAUD out of the room , she resisting laughingly , and closes the door .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Holding the slippers aloft .Gendlemen ! Homage to Beaudy ! Vollow me ! Zam ! Vinzent ! Rober ! Neego ! Eddie !The men put themselves behind him , in single file , in the order in which he calls them , with the exception of JEYES , who deliberately sits at the writing-table , and FARNCOMBE , who is embarrassed . JIMMIE claps her hands and MRS. UPJOHN , who is pouring out tea , laughs herself into a fit of coughing .Ta , ta , ra , ra , ta , ta ! Boum , boum !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Baron , you great baby !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Quig ! Marge !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Calling to FARNCOMBE .Come along , Farncombe !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Giving FARNCOMBE a shove .Go on !

div.stage: FARNCOMBE takes his place behind ROPER and , headed by VON RETTENMAYER , the men march round the room .

lg.stage: Waving the slippers in the air and singing .
lg.l: Weib , was ist in aller Welt

div.stage: VON RETTENMAYER halts before LILY and kneels to her . She extends her left foot and he kisses her instep and puts her foot into her slipper . She rewards him by lightly boxing his ears . He makes way for DE CASTRO , handing him the other slipper , and DE CASTRO performs the same ceremony with LILY 'S right foot . She upsets DE CASTRO 'S balance by a little kick .

DE CASTRO gathers himself up and sits in the chair at the end of the settee in front of the , writing-table . BLAND and ROPER , having knelt and kissed LILY 'S foot , also sit , the former in the chair in the middle of the room , the latter in the chair on the extreme left . Finally , FARNCOMBE finds himself before LILY . He looks at her hesitatingly and she returns his look with awakened interest and withdraws her foot .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Shaking her head .No , no ; do n't you be silly , like the others .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Loudly .Tea !

div.stage: BLAND , VON RETTENMAYER and DE CASTRO jump up and go to the tea-table where FARNCOMBE joins them . GLADYS enters , carrying a stand on which are a plate of bread-and-butter , a dish of cake , etc . ROPER takes the stand from her and the girl retires . FARNCOMBE brings LILY a cup of tea . DE CASTRO and BLAND follow him , the one with a milk-jug , the other with a sugar-basin . VON RETTENMAYER carries a cup of tea to JIMMIE , and then DE CASTRO and BLAND , having waited upon LILY , go to JIMMIE with the milk and sugar . ROPER hands the bread-and-butter and cake to LILY , then to JIMMIE , and in the end ROPER , BLAND , DE CASTRO and VON RETTENMAYER assemble at the tea-table and receive their cups of tea from MRS. UPJOHN .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Relieving GLADYS of the stand .Give it to me . I want a little exercise .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Taking her cup of tea from FARNCOMBE .Thanks .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Helping LILY to milk .Milk-ho !

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Sugar ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Br-r-r-rh ! I 'm putting on weight as it is .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Offering the bread-and-butter , etc .— facetiously .Ices , sweets or chocolates , full piano-score !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Nothing to eat , Uncle ; I dine at six .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Calling to JEYES from the tea-table .Captain , ai n't you goin ’ to ‘ ave any tea ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Moodily examining the presents on the writing-table .No , thank you , Mrs. Upjohn .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: To JIMMIE , after she has been helped to milk .Sugar ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Two lumps .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Pushing BLAND and DE CASTRO aside , imitating a female voice .Ices , sweets or chocolates , full piano-score !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Cutting a slice of cake .Lal , the world ‘ ud be a much happier place to live in if Lloyd George taxed your jokes . VON RETTENMAYER , BLAND , and DE CASTRO .Returning to the tea-table .Ha , ha , ha , ha !

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The scene is an artistically decorated refreshment-saloon — or “ foyer ” — on the first-circle floor of a theatre . The wall facing the spectator is panelled partly in glass , and through the glazed panels the corridor behind the circle , and the doors admitting to the circle , are seen . The right-hand wall is panelled in a similar way , showing the landing at the top of the principal staircase and an entrance to the corridor . Some music-stands and stools are on the landing , arranged for a small orchestra .

In the right-hand wall there is a double swing-door giving on to the landing ; and in the wall at the back , opening on to , and from , the corridor , there is a single swing-door on the left and another on the right . The left-hand door is fastened back into the saloon by a hook . Between the two doors in the back wall runs the refreshment-counter .

In one of the further corners of the saloon there is a plaster statue representing the Muse of Comedy , in the opposite corner a companion figure of Dancing . In the wall on the left , the grate hidden by flowers , is a fireplace with a fender-stool before it , and on either side of the fireplace there is a capacious and richly upholstered arm-chair . A settee of like design stands against the wall on the right between the double-door and the spectator .

The counter is decked-out as a sideboard , and at equal distances from each other there are four round tables laid for a supper-party of twenty-six persons . There are eight chairs at one table and six at each of the others , the chairs being of the sort usually supplied by ball-caterers .
The saloon and the landing without are brilliantly lighted , the corridor less brightly .

sp.p: Picking up FARNCOMBE 'S card .Oh , have it your own way .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Picking up VON RETTENMAYER 'S card .Besides , the Baron 's sweet on Enid just now ; I 'm sure he 'd prefer —They exchange the cards and rearrange them .thanks , ol ’ man . Sorry I was shirty .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Laying down his plan and cards and producing a letter from his breast-pocket .By-the-bye , the fair Lily — the heroine of the party , as you call her — is in a pretty tantrum over the whole business .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Tantrum ?

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Unfolding the letter .Had this from her ten minutes ago . Listen to this .Reading .“ My Dressing-room . 11-15 . 80 degrees , with the windows open . ”In an injured tone .Haw , so I should think !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Concerned .What 's amiss ?

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Reading .“ Morrie , you pig . ”ROPER whistles .“ Morrie , you pig . I should feel deeply indebted to you if you would kindly inform me why the devil you went out of your way to deceive me last night . You led me to suppose — and so did that lying worm Lal Roper —— ”looking at ROPERYou .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Oh , lord !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Resuming .“ — that lying worm Lal Roper —— ”

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Testily .All right , all right .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: “ — you both led me to suppose that this rotten banquet was to be a family gathering of the ladies and gentlemen of the Pandora Theatre , and no outsiders asked . Now I find that only three or four of the men of the Company are invited , and I hear from Nita Trevenna , who has got it from young Kennedy , that several of the Boys are to be laid on for the occasion . The result is you have made me tell a regular whopper to a particular friend of mine with regard to this affair —— ”

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Passing his hand over his brow .Nicko Jeyes .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: “ — which I will never forgive you for , Morris Cooling — neither you nor Lal Roper . As true as I am alive , I have a jolly good mind not to show , but to put on my old rags and go straight home . You are two cads . So take it out of that and believe me , Always yours affectionately , Lil . ”

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Walking about .Well , I 'm blessed !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Returning the letter to his pocket .Haw ! Tasty document !

lg.l: Lying worm and a cad ! And from Miss Lily Margaret Upjohn !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: No ; waited for you .Going on with his arrangements at the tables .You 're responsible . What I did last night was simply to oblige a pal .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Irresolutely .I 'd better run round to her , and try to smooth her down , had n't I ?

lg.l: Why you wanted to mislead the girl I can n't understand .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Damn it , you agreed that that sulky brute Jeyes ‘ ud be a wet blanket ! You blow hot and cold , you do !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: There you go ! More filthy temper !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: If ever I assist in getting up another party ——!As he reaches the door on the left , he encounters CARLTON SMYTHE , who is entering at that moment , and puts on his humourous manner .Hul-lo ! Here we are again ! All change for Oxford Circus !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: A bulky , sleepy-looking man with grey hair , a darker moustache and beard , and a heavy , rolling gait .Ha , Lal !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: I 'm just going to have a word with Lil Parradell .

div.stage: He disappears and SMYTHE advances .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Approaching SMYTHE .How are you to-night , Chief ?

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: A silk hat on the back of his head , an overcoat on his arm — regarding the preparations with disgust .Puh ! Here 's a muck and a muddle !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Do n't worry ; we 'll clear it away in no time . Shall I tell you who are coming ?

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: No ; I shall know soon enough . What was the house to-night ?

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Producing a long slip of paper and handing it to SMYTHE .Big .SMYTHE scans the paper through half-closed lids and gives a growl of contentment .Haw ! And the weather dead against us .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Screwing up the paper , and cramming it into his waistcoat-pocket .There 's no bad weather for a good play .Looking at his hands .I 'll go and have a wash and brush up .LUIGI returns , entering at the door on the left , and goes behind the counter . The waiters follow him , carrying some melons lying upon ice in plated dishes . They deposit the dishes upon the counter and LUIGI proceeds to cut the melon into slices . COOLING resumes , at a table on the left , the placing of the cards . As SMYTHE is moving towards the right-hand door at the back , STEWART HENEAGE and GERALD GRIMWOOD — two exquisitely dressed youths with blank faces — enter from the landing . SMYTHE shakes hands with them .Ha , Mr. Heneage ! Ha , Mr. Grimwood !HENEAGE and GRIMWOOD murmur some polite expressions .Excuse me ; I 'm just going to wash my hands .DE CASTRO enters , also at the double-door , and SMYTHE shakes hands with him . HENEAGE and GRIMWOOD drift over to COOLING , who hails them warmly .How do , Sam ! Back in a moment ; just going to wash my hands .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Detaining him .I thay , Carlton .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Lowering his voice .I 've been in front again to-night . Magnifithent ! Marvellouth !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Resignedly .It 'll do ; I shall get a couple o ’ years out of it .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: There'th jutht one little improvement I 'd like to thee , if I may thuggetht it .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Linking his arm in SMYTHE 'S .You 're thure you wo n't conthider me prethumptuouth ?

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Of course not ; very kind of yer .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: In SMYTHE 'S ear .If you could give Gabth — Mith Kato — a tiny bit more to do in the thecond act ——!

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Nodding .Ah , yes , yes .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: She'th a little lump o ’ talent , that gal , if you only realithed it ; a perfect little lump o ’ talent .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Trying to escape .Er — I 'll think it over .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Will yer ! An extra thong ! That'th all it need be — an extra thong ! Oh , it would be thuch an improvement !VON RETTENMAYER enters at the double-door . The waiters now go to the tables and lay a plate with a slice of melon upon it at each cover .Here'th the Baron . We 've been thitting together to-night , I and the Baron .Wringing SMYTHE 'S hand .Thankth .Joining COOLING and the others on the left as SMYTHE greets VON RETTENMAYER .Hullo , Morrith !Shaking hands with HENEAGE and GRIMWOOD .Well , boyth !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Shaking hands with VON RETTENMAYER .Glad to see yer , Baron .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Zo good of you to haf me .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Excuse me ; I 'm just going to wash my hands .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Detaining him .Bardon me — one moment ——

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Dropping his voice .May I dake the liberdy of indulging in a liddle griticism on your eggcellent blay ?

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Drawing SMYTHE away from the tables .Gome here .His mouth close to SMYTHE 'S ear .The zecond aggd !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Second act ; what 's the matter with it ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: The pard where the gharming Miss Barradell is ghanging her gostume ——

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: That is where the biece reguires lifding —with a gesturelifding .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Lifting ?

lg.l: Mr. Davish — Mr . Balk — eggsdremely glever ;
but if you could zee your way glear to gif Enid — Miss

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Nodding .Ah , h 'm , h 'm .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: It would remove the zolitary imberfection .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Er — I 'll think it over .Releasing himself .I 'm just going to wash my hands . We 'll talk about it later .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Schoensten Dank .Going to the men on the left .Aha , Mr. Gooling ! My dear Steward — my dear Jerry ——!

div.stage: As SMYTHE is again making for the door on the left , MRS. STIDULPH enters from the landing with COLONEL STIDULPH .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: To MRS. STIDULPH .Ha , Dolly !Kissing her .How are you , my dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: A mature but still beautiful woman , gorgeously dressed and wearing showy jewels — with a lofty air .How are you , Carlton ?

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: To STIDULPH .How d'ye do , Arthur ? Delighted to see yer .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Lucky I 'm able to come to you to-night . It 's so difficult to catch me in the season .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Been in front ?

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: M'yes ;in a tone of boredomoh , yes .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: What , do n't you like it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Oh , I do n't say I dislike it ;shrugging her shouldersbut one can n't forget what one used to do here in the old days .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: An elderly , distinguished-looking man with a meek voice and a courteous but rather nervous manner .I 've had a most enjoyable evening , Carlton . So bright ; so very bright !

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: To STIDULPH , sneeringly .Oh , anything pleases you ; you 'd laugh at Punch and Judy .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: I 'm just running away to wash my hands .Looking towards the men on the left .You know Von Rettenmayer ?

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Know him ! Why , he was about in my time !Crossing to VON RETTENMAYER , followed by STIDULPH .Karl !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: My dear lady !Kissing her hand perfunctorily .What bliss !Shaking hands with STIDULPH .Golonel !

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Shaking hands with DE CASTRO .How are you , Sam ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Ah , Dolly !To STIDULPH .Hullo , Arthur !

lg.stage: Presenting HENEAGE and GRIMWOOD to the STIDULPHS .

div.stage: As the STIDULPHS leave SMYTHE , HERBERT FULKERSON enters from the landing with FARNCOMBE . In dumb-show , SMYTHE and FULKERSON greet each other and then FULKERSON introduces FARNCOMBE .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Shaking hands with FARNCOMBE .Glad to make your acquaintance .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Glad to make yours , Mr. Smythe — and in such circumstances !

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: A white-faced young man with red eyes and of dissipated appearance — espying MRS. STIDULPH .By Jove , if it is n't Dolly Ensor !Hurrying to MRS. STIDULPH .What cheer , Dolly !

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Coldly .How do you do , Mr. Fulkerson ?

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Slightly abashed .Oh , I — I 'm pretty middlin ’ , thanks ; hope you 're the same .Nodding to STIDULPH .Evenin ’ , Arthur .

div.stage: VINCENT BLAND has sauntered in at the door on the left and now joins the group surrounding the STIDULPHS .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Nodding to HENEAGE and GRIMWOOD .H'lo , Stewart ! H'lo , Jerry !Coming to the STIDULPHS .Dolly —— Colonel ——

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE .I 'll be back in a minute or two ; I 'm just going to wash my hands .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Calling to FARNCOMBE .Hi ! Eddie !

div.stage: FARNCOMBE crosses to FULKERSON and is presented by him to the STIDULPHS . GABRIELLE KATO enters at the right-hand door at the back , meeting SMYTHE as he is going out . The waiters have finished setting the plates of melon upon the tables and now withdraw , carrying the plated dishes and preceded by LUIGI , at the door on the left .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: To GABRIELLE .Ha , Gabby , my dear ! Quite well , eh ?

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: A pretty young woman with a fretful little face expressive of extreme dissatisfaction with the world — looking at SMYTHE spiritlessly .This is a treat . Why , you have n't been to see us for ages .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Cunningly .I see you all far oftener than you suspect .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Do you ? That is sly of you .

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Leaving her .I 'm just going to have a wash and brush up .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Really ? Oh , you are full of news .

div.stage: He departs as DE CASTRO approaches GABRIELLE .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: In a low voice .Hullo , Gabth ! How are you to-night ?

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Oh , I 'm all right , I s'pose . Is n't it hot ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Not at his ease with her .It ith inclined that way .

div.stage: DAPHNE DURE , NITA TREVENNA , DOUGLAS GLYNN , and ALBERT PALK enter at the door on the left . NITA is a tall , handsome girl , DAPHNE a plump , little , fair , baby-faced thing . They are charmingly dressed , as are all the ladies of the Pandora Theatre . GLYNN and PALK — the latter a short , thick-set man who might reasonably be a low comedian — are two professional-looking gentlemen of the best class . The arrivals are warmly hailed by FULKERSON , VON RETTENMAYER , HENEAGE , and GRIMWOOD and , with more reserve , by MRS. STIDULPH . STIDULPH has seated himself wearily in the armchair on the nearer side of the fireplace and , beyond listening to BLAND who is talking to him , has withdrawn himself from the proceedings .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE .Here 's Daphne Dure — and Nita Trevenna .Going to the new comers .Hullo , Daphne ! Hullo , Nita ! How'r ' yer , Douglas ! Hullo , Albert ! DAPHNE and NITA . How d'ye do , Bertie ?To VON RETTENMAYER .How d'ye do , Von ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Kissing their hands .Dear ladies !To GLYNN and PALK .Aha , Mr. Glynn — Mr . Balk —! DAPHNE and NITA .

div.stage: To HENEAGE and GRIMWOOD . ] How d'ye do , Stewie ? How d'ye do , Jerry ? [ To MRS . STIDULPH . ] Oh , Dolly ! That you , Dolly ?

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Well , girls !

lg.l: Here ! I want to introdooce Lord Farncombe . Miss Dure — Miss Trevenna —
Lord Farncombe . Douglas — Albert — Lord Farncombe .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Pouncing upon Cooling .I say , Morris !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: What is it , my dear ?

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Is it true that little Kennedy 's met with an accident ?

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Yes ; can n't join us .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: The Dwarf ! What 's happened ?

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Ran his car into a ‘ bus , just outside the theatre .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Pitched himself forward on to his head .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: His head !

sp.speaker: DAPHNE
sp.p: With a simper .Do n't be anxious , Nita ; there 's nothing to hurt there .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Poor Dwarf !

div.stage: GABRIELLE and DE CASTRO now move over to the others .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Hullo , Gabs ! Hullo , Sam !

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Ah , Bertie !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Kissing GABRIELLE 'S hand .Gabrielle !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Shaking hands .Daphne — Nita — Douglath — Albert —!

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: I want to introdooce Lord Farncombe . Miss Kato — Lord Farncombe ——

div.stage: A band of musicians have mustered upon the landing and there is the sound of the tuning of instruments .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Hurrying across to the double-door .No , no ; no music yet . Wait for Miss Parradell !As he reaches the double-door , ROPER enters quickly at the right-hand door at the back and seizes his arm .Eh ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To COOLING .It 's all right ; she 'll be round in a minute .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Amiable ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Angelic . She 's wearing a new dress , and that 's taken her mind off it .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Her bark 's always worse than her bite . I knew it ‘ ud blow over .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Formidably .Oh , but I have given her such a talking to !COOLING passes through the double-door , and instructs the leader of the band , while ROPER bustles over to the throng on the left .Hul-lo !Imitating a street news-vendor .Speshul edishun , cricket , py-per !Shaking hands all round .Dolly — Nita — Gabs — Daphne ! Douglas — Albert ! Ah , here you are , Farncombe !Discovering STIDULPH .Hul-lo , Colonel ! Results , py-per , extry speshul !

div.stage: ENID MONCREIFF , WILFRID TAVISH , and SIGISMUND SHIRLEY enter at the right-hand door at the back . ENID is a long , spare-figured girl with the lissom walk of a dancer ; TAVISH and SHIRLEY are tall , clean-shaven men of gentlemanlike appearance . VON RETTENMAYER makes for ENID eagerly and is followed , at a more moderate pace , by HENEAGE , GRIMWOOD , and DE CASTRO , and by FULKERSON bringing FARNCOMBE .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Miss Mongreiff !Kissing ENID 'S hand with fervour .Your dancing was more zurprizing to-night than ever .To TAVISH and SHIRLEY .Aha , my friends !

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Shaking hands with HENEAGE , GRIMWOOD , and DE CASTRO .Well , Stew ! How are you , Jerry ! Sam !

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: I want to introdooce Lord Farncombe . Miss Moncreiff — Lord Farncombe .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Hurrying across .Hul-lo , here 's Enid !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Shaking hands with TAVISH and SHIRLEY .Piethe went thplendidly thith evenin ’ , did n't it ?

lg.stage: Shaking hands with TAVISH and SHIRLEY .
lg.l: Farncombe . Mr. Tavish — Mr. Shirley — Lord Farncombe .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Coming forward to greet MRS. STIDULPH who advances to her .Dolly dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Embracing ENID .Enid darling ! Good gracious , you 're becoming an absolute skeleton !

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Indeed ? Well , no one can say that of you .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: It is a pleasure , meeting all you girls to-night . Of course , one can n't help seeing changes .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Icily .Ah , it must be a pleasure , that .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: I 'm going to scold dear old Carlton by-and-by . He never gave me a birthday-party when I was with him .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: No ; and you had so many birthdays here , had n't you ?

div.stage: COOLING returns , entering from the landing , and , after looking at the assembly , goes out at the right-hand door at the back . At the same moment , FLO CONNIFY , SYBIL DERMOTT , OLGA COOK , and EVANGELINE VENTRIS — four statuesque beauties with impassive faces — enter at the door on the left . OLGA is in a dark gown and EVANGELINE is wearing a rather elaborate head-dress . Instantly there is a movement in the direction of the new arrivals on the part of ROPER , HENEAGE , and GRIMWOOD . DE CASTRO and FULKERSON follow , FULKERSON still leading FARNCOMBE about with him . MRS. STIDULPH turns from ENID disdainfully and joins NITA and DAPHNE at the fireplace . TAVISH and SHIRLEY also move to the left , where they come upon STIDULPH and shake hands with him , while VON RETTENMAYER and ENID , the latter flushed with victory , seat themselves upon the settee on the right .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Hastening to the beauties .Hul-lo ! Show your tickets , please ! Room inside for four !Shaking hands .How are you , Flo ! How are you , Sybil ! How are you , Olga ! I say , look at ‘ Vangy !

sp.p: As the men shake hands with them , mechanically .How d'ye do ? How d'ye do ? How d'ye do ? How d'ye do ?

sp.speaker: THE FOUR BEAUTIES
sp.p: As before .How d'ye do ? How d'ye do ? How d'ye do ? How d'ye do ?

div.stage: COOLING hurries back .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: To everybody .Miss Parradell !Opening the double-door and signalling to the leader of the band .Now !

div.stage: The band strikes up the air of “ Mind the Paint ” as LILY enters at the right-hand door at the back with JIMMIE BIRCH . LILY is dressed in white , and altogether fulfils exteriorly ROPER 'S description of “ angelic . ” She carries a large bouquet of lilies and pale roses with a broad ribbon flowing from it . All the men but FARNCOMBE , who holds aloof , press round her , STIDULPH rising and joining them . The ladies follow .

sp.speaker: THE MEN
sp.p: Struggling for her hand .Many happy returns of day ! Many happy returns of the day ! Many happy returns of the day !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Battling with the men .Keep away from her ! Bertie , you 're on her frock ! Mind her frock !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Mind the paint !

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE MEN
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Holding her bouquet above her head .My roses ! Be careful of me , boys ! One at a time !

sp.speaker: THE MEN
sp.p: Many happy returns of the day !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I want to kiss the girls . Girls ——!

div.stage: The men make way for the ladies who come to LILY .

sp.speaker: THE LADIES
sp.p: Many happy returns of the day !

lg.l: Sybil — Nita —! Oh , Mrs . Stidulph !— Enid —
Daphne — Gabs — Flo dear — Olga — ‘ Vangy ——!

sp.speaker: PALK
sp.p: Suddenly .Here 's the guv'nor !

div.stage: SMYTHE enters at the door on the left . LUIGI and the waiters are behind him , the waiters carrying trays on which are sugar-casters and dishes of powdered ginger . At once there is a movement towards SMYTHE of everybody except those who have already greeted him , and LILY who is detained by ROPER and others .

sp.speaker: TAVISH
sp.p: How are you , guv'nor ?

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE LADIES
sp.p: How d'ye do , Mr. Smythe ?

sp.speaker: OTHER LADIES
sp.p: Hustling him .How are you , Carlton ?

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: In the midst of them all .Girls , girls ! I 'll shake hands with you all in turn , girls .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Thought you were dead .

sp.speaker: DAPHNE
sp.p: Yes ; look at Olga — she 's in deep mourning .

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE LADIES
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Shaking hands .Do n't , girls , do n't ; you 're smothering me .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: During a momentary lull , finding FARNCOMBE standing before her and raising her eyebrows .You !Giving him her hand carelessly .Oh , it is n't long before we meet again , is it ?

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Puffing and blowing .That 's the lot of yer . Phew ! Where 's Lily ? Lily here ?The crowd divides , to allow him to advance . Seeing LILY , he opens his arms and she goes to him and lays her head upon his breast .Lil —patting her shouldersmy dear !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Half gaily , half tearfully .Ha , ha , ha ! Carlton !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Go'blessyer !In another tone .Well , what about something to eat !

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Ready , Mr. Smythe .Loudly .Ladies and gentlemen , supper is ready !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: Ha !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: At the principal table .Here you are , Chief ! Miss Parradell !

sp.speaker: SMYTHE
sp.p: To LILY .Come along !

div.stage: There is a general hunt for places and much hubbub and confusion .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Calling to ROPER .Lal , that 's your table .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Imitating a shop-walker .Mr. Roper , forward !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Mrs. Stidulph ! Lord Farncombe !Pointing to another table .Glynn , you 're there .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Here you are , Daphne !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: At his table .Miss Kato , wanted !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Calling to GABRIELLE .Gabth !

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Calling to HENEAGE .Stewie !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Baron — Enid ——

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Aha !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: To STIDULPH .Over there , Colonel .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Wandering about .Where am I ? Where am I ?

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Pushing him aside .Oh , be off !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Calling .Jimmie !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: At his place at a table .Olga , you 're here . Mr. Grimwood !

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Where am I ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To FULKERSON .Next to me , worse luck .Screwing up her face at him .Ugh !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Ladies ’ mantles on the second-floor !

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: Where 's Sybil ?

sp.speaker: DAPHNE
sp.p: Calling .Syb ! Syb !

div.stage: The curtain falls , but the music of “ Mind the Paint ” continues for a while . Then it ceases and , after a short silence , the curtain rises again . The supper-tables have disappeared and the saloon is empty of people . The musicians and their music-stands and stools have also gone , and faintly from the distance comes the sound of a waltz . Two settees , matching the rest of the furniture , now stand in the centre of the saloon back-to-back , one of them facing the counter , the other facing the spectator . LILY 'S bouquet lies on the nearer of the two settees , and upon the floor there is a fan , a red rose that has fallen from a lady 's corsage , and a pocket-handkerchief with a powder-puff peeping from it . On the counter there are carafes of lemonade , decanters of spirits and syphons of soda-water , a bowl of strawberries-and-cream , various dishes of cakes , boxes of cigars and cigarettes , a lighted spirit-lamp , and other adjuncts of a buffet . COLONEL STIDULPH wanders in through the double-door as the waltz comes to an end . Feebly and dejectedly he goes to the counter , takes a cigarette , and is lighting it when LUIGI and the waiters enter the door on the left . Two of the waiters are carrying bottles of champagne in wine-coolers , another brings a tray on which are champagne-glasses and tumblers , and the bearded waiter follows with a large dish of sandwiches .

lg.stage: Behind the counter — to STIDULPH , familiarly .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Dancing — I ?Shaking his head .No .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Who speaks Cockney English with a slight foreign ascent — cutting the wire of a champagne bottle .Why , you used to be a regular slap-up dancing man when I first knew you .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Nodding .Ah , ah ;moving awaymy dancing days are done .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Done ! Oh , I like that ! I bet you ai n't sixty , come now , eh ?

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: What 's the time , Luigi ? I have n't a watch on .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Time , Colonel ?Looking at his watch .Twenty to three .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: No later ?Sitting on the settee on the right , with a sigh .Oh , dear !

div.stage: One of the waiters goes out , in obedience to a direction from LUIGI , at the door on the left as HENEAGE enters with ENID , GRIMWOOD with NITA , and VON RETTENMAYER with MRS. STIDULPH at the right-hand door at the back . A wisp of hair has fallen over HENEAGE 'S forehead , GRIMWOOD looks somewhat downcast , and VON RETTENMAYER is obviously bored by MRS. STIDULPH .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: To HENEAGE , walking across to the left .Never been to Ostend ! You 've never been born , then . I 'm counting the hours to my holiday .Sitting in the chair on the nearer side of the fireplace .Hôtel de la Plage . Why do n't you run over while I 'm there ?

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: To GRIMWOOD , following ENID .My dear boy , I give you my solemn word it was n't you . It was that fool Bertie . Anyhow , it 's a rotten old frock .Showing a small rent in her skirt to ENID , gaily .Pom , pa-ra , rom , pom , pom !

div.stage: HENEAGE and GRIMWOOD go to the counter , secure a waiter , and return with him to ENID and NITA . The waiter receives his orders and presently fetches the ladies glasses of lemonade .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Whispering to VON RETTENMAYER .Well ! Did you ever ! Just fancy !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Absently , looking at ENID .I beg your bardon ?

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Fancy those two girls walking into a room before us !Discovering the fan upon the floor .Oh , I do believe that 's my fan !

div.stage: VON RETTENMAYER restores the fan to MRS. STIDULPH as ROPER and GABRIELLE enter at the door on the left .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: To ROPER , in a low , complaining voice .It 's a shame of you ; that 's what it is . You went and put Lily Parradell into rubber and enabled her to make a bit . She told us so .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Yes ; but how long ago ?

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: That 's not the point . The point is , it 's always Lily Parradell with you ; you never do anything for us other girls .

div.stage: She sits upon the nearer settee in the centre and she and ROPER , he standing by her , continue their conversation .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: To VON RETTENMAYER .No , thanks ; I 'm on a diet . Did n't you notice me at supper ?Moving to the settee on the right .Let 's sit .To STIDULPH .Oh , get up .STIDULPH rises quickly .Why are n't you dancing ? If you do n't dance , go home and put yourself to bed . You might , for all the good you 're doing here .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: With a forced , painful laugh .Ha , ha ! Ha , ha , ha !

lg.l: Blenty of room for you too ,

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: No , no ; I wo n't inconvenience you .

div.stage: He moves away and VON RETTENMAYER sits beside MRS. STIDULPH . The waiter who has previously gone out now returns at the door on the left with a tray of ices in paper cases . He goes to the counter for a supply of ice-spoons as FARNCOMBE enters with LILY at the right-hand door at the back . Her cheeks are flushed , her eyes sparkling .

lg.stage: All his attention suddenly directed to LILY and FARNCOMBE .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Excitedly , seizing STIDULPH 'S hand .You 're not dancing , Colonel Stidulph .Showing him her programme .Dance with me . I 'll make one of the others give up a dance for you .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Going to the counter .No , no ; I 'm too old .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Too old for dancing ! I shall never be too old for dancing .Coming to the nearer settee in the centre , picking up her bouquet , and sitting beside GABRIELLE .Ah-h-h-h !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE , who follows LILY .Hul-lo !Beaming .Jolly party , hey , Farncombe ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Boyishly .Lovely !To LILY .May I bring you some lemonade — an ice ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Looking up at him .You may keep on bringing me ices till the music starts again .FARNCOMBE leaves her .Gabby , was n't that waltz delicious !

div.stage: PALK and SYBIL enter at the door on the left . SYBIL seats herself beside NITA on the fender-stool and PALK fetches her some refreshment .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: To LILY , drearily .I say , Lil .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: How much did you make out of rubber last year through Lal ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rubber , rubber , rubber ? Br-r-r-rh ! I do n't know .To ROPER .How much ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Four-fifty .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: There !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I did my house up with it — gave the job to young Charlie Ramsden who 's gone in for decorating ——

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Yes , and blued the whole lot at one go !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Laughing .Blued it completely . Ha , ha , ha !Singing .“ What does the blue sea Whisper to me-ee —! ”FARNCOMBE appears at her side with the waiter carrying the ices .Ices !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Leaving GABRIELLE and , with his hands in his pockets , walking about exultingly .Ices , sweets or chocolates , full piano-score ! Hul-lo , here ! Ha , ha , ha !

div.stage: GLYNN and OLGA and DE CASTRO and EVANGELINE have entered at the right-hand door at the back . OLGA and EVANGELINE seat themselves upon the further settee in the centre and GLYNN and DE CASTRO summon a waiter to attend upon them . SHIRLEY and FLO now enter at the door on the left and go to the counter . At the same moment SMYTHE , COOLING , and TAVISH enter at the right-hand door at the back , SMYTHE smoking a huge cigar . They also stand at the counter and are served with drinks by LUIGI . LILY and GABRIELLE having each taken an ice , the waiter with the ices moves away and offers his ices to the other ladies . Another waiter carries round a tray on which are a box of cigarettes and the spirit-lamp , and the bearded waiter moves about with the dish of sandwiches . Some of the ladies light cigarettes , a few of the men take sandwiches .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: As he enters with SMYTHE and TAVISH .Haw , haw , haw ! You 're wonderful , Chief .To TAVISH .The Chief 's in great form , Willy .To STIDULPH .Colonel , listen to the Chief .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: To VON RETTENMAYER , confidentially .Of course , this is strictly between ourselves — though I almost hinted as much to Smythe — but the fact is the Pandora is n't in the least what it was , Karl .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Noding is what it was , my dear Dolly , and nobody .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Fanning herself .I suppose he can n't find the artists ; that 's it . If you do n't have the artists —!Shutting up her fan .You recollect my “ Polly Taggart ” in The Merry Milliner ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Stifling a yawn .Gharming ; gharming .

div.stage: FARNCOMBE is bending over LILY while she is eating her ice and they are talking lightly but intently . GABRIELLE , finding that she is “ out of it , ” rises with a pout and , carrying her plate , joins the ladies and men who are at the fireplace . BLAND enters with JIMMIE at the door on the left .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: To VON RETTENMAYER .I hate blowing my own trumpet , but I was looking through my press-cuttings only yesterday . I 've never seen such notices as I had for “ Polly Taggart . ”

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Closing his eyes .Vavourable ?

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: Favourable ! They make me blush to read them . Stupid of me ; but they make me blush , positively .

div.stage: JIMMIE comes to LILY , BLAND following her . On her way she sees the handkerchief and powder-puff lying upon the floor .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
