sp.p: Why , there it is !Picking up the handkerchief and puff , and rubbing the puff , which is an extremely ragged one , over her nose — singing sentimentally .“ There are no friends like the old friends , The constant , tried , and true ;— ”Sitting beside LILY .Room for a little ‘ un ?

div.stage: LILY , without interrupting her talk with FARNCOMBE , lays her hand on JIMMIE 'S for a moment .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: To JIMMIE .Bring you anything ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Wrapping the puff in the handkerchief tenderly and slipping it into her bosom .A liqueur of petrol and a lucifer-match .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Leaving her .Oh , go on !

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: To VON RETTENMAYER .And then to give it all up , as I was idiot enough to do when I married , and for a life as dull as ditch-water ! If ever a woman sacrificed herself in this world ——!

div.stage: FULKERSON and DAPHNE enter at the door on the left and hurry to the counter .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Boisterously .Time ! Time !To those standing at the counter .‘ Low me . ‘ Low me .To LUIGI .Glass o ’ lemonade and a whiskey-and-soda . Quick with the whiskey-and-soda .

sp.speaker: MRS. STIDULPH
sp.p: To VON RETTENMAYER .But I do n't intend to stick to that arrangement . If I can n't get back into the theatres , there are the halls ! I was telling the Colonel this morning ——

lg.stage: Appearing before MRS. STIDULPH , his programme in his hand .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Rising with alacrity .Aha !Bowing to MRS. STIDULPH .I yield with relugtance .

div.stage: ROPER sits beside MRS. STIDULPH and VON RETTENMAYER hastens to ENID .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To MRS. STIDULPH .Another waltz .

lg.stage: To HENEAGE , who is claiming her .
lg.l: Wait till I 've finished my drink ,

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: To NITA .Nita .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: No ; this is with Douglas .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Nothing o ’ the sort .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Referring to her programme .You 're correct ; my mistake .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Coming to GABRIELLE who is talking to SYBIL .Gabth .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Dolefully .Oh , you again !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Mortified .Afraid tho .

div.stage: The sound of distant music is again heard , and there is a great deal of bustle as the men claim their partners . TAVISH goes to EVANGELINE , GRIMWOOD to , FLO , PALK and GLYNN to OLGA and SYBIL , and gradually the assemblage melts away .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Coming to JIMMIE , who is conning her programme , and standing before her — reading from his programme .“ Vawlse . Cry dee cure . ”

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: With withering accuracy .“ Valse . Cri de coeur . ”

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Wagging his head .Very likely . Come along , Jimmie .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Rising and shaking herself out .Jane to you , if you please .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Tosh !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: I was christened Jane , Herbert .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Well , I was n't at the christening , see .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: No ; but if you are not more careful of those feet of yours while you 're waltzing , you will be at my funeral .

div.stage: She takes his arm and they go out at the door on the left . SMYTHE , STIDULPH , COOLING , and SHIRLEY follow , talking together . All the couples have now disappeared except VON RETTENMAYER and ENID and FARNCOMBE and LILY . VON RETTENMAYER and ENID are at the counter , where LUIGI is giving VON RETTENMAYER a glass of champagne , and the waiters are busying themselves in collecting the soiled glasses , plates , etc ., which have been left upon the mantel-piece and chairs . The bearded waiter comes to LILY and she hands him her plate .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: To LILY .Shall we go down ?

div.stage: She rises , leaving her bouquet upon the settee , and is about to put her arm through FARNCOMBE 'S when she checks herself and looks at her programme .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Frowning .Tsss !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a low voice .One , two , three , four —! Why , this — this is our fifth dance !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Softly .Yes .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Five out of eight !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Looking at his programme .And 10 , 12 , and 14 are mine , too .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With a movement of her shoulders , accepting his arm .How unfair !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: As they go to the right-hand door at the back .Unfair ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To the others . I can n't think what made me so thoughtless .

div.stage: They disappear . Two of the waiters carry out the soiled glasses , etc . ; another follows with the ices , and the bearded waiter with the strawberries-and-cream . After a while , LUIGI also withdraws .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Leaving the counter with VON RETTENMAYER .Well , what did you say to him ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: I told him the biece wants lifding in the zecond aggd and that he ought to gif you anoder dance .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: On the right .What did he say ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: He will think it over !

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Scornfully .Ha ! That 's Smythe 's invariable formula , cunning old fox !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: But we are to dalk aboud it lader . I am waiding to ged him alone .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Pff ! You wo n't get him alone , you stupid ; he 'll take precious good care of that .Finding that LUIGI and the waiters have departed , and walking across to the left .Ah , but it is n't dancing my mind 's dwelling on just now , dear boy .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Following her .Nod ?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: It 's rest I 'm yearning for — my holiday !— rest for my weary bones .Turning to him without a sign of disturbance .Karl , I 'm simply bursting with rage .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Rage ?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: That wretched hotel at Ostend — the Plage ! They 've the confounded impudence to ask me a hundred-and-twenty-five francs a day for two cubby-holes on the third floor , for my aunt and me .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Monsdrous .With a shrug .But Ostend is — Ostend .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Thanks for the information . Is that all the sympathy you can offer ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Bardon .Humbly .There may be gheaper hodels .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Where the common people pay for their beds and meals with Cook 's coupons !Sitting upon the arm of the further settee in the centre and swinging her feet .Oh , it does n't matter . I suppose it 'll have to be Swanage , or some brisk resort of that description .Sighing .So be it !Humming .Tra , lal , lal , la ——!

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Sitting on the nearer settee in the centre , close to her , with an anxious expression .A hundred-and-twendy-five frangks a day ?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Including nothing — absolutely nothing !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Biting his nails .Prezisely ! There 's the eading and dringking .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: One can n't starve , that 's certain .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Which would amound to ——?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Watching him out of the corner of her eye .I believe aunt and I could manage to feed ourselves on forty francs a day — or fifty — at a pinch .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: His face growing longer and longer .A hundred-and-twendy-five — and fifdy ——

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: A hundred-and-seventy-five .Stroking his hair with a finger .Call it two hundred .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Leaning back appalled .Fifdy-sigs bounds a weeg !

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Sixty , in round figures .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: For a fordnight ?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Oh , no , dear ; a fortnight 's no use .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: But one begomes sig of a blace afder a fordnight .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: If you only go for enjoyment ; not if you go for rest — rest .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Three weegs , then ?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: A month . Smythe gives me the whole of August .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Passing his hand across his forehead .A month !

lg.stage: Rising and carefully picking a piece of fluff from her skirt .
lg.l: We 're losing this dance . Shall we have a turn ?

div.stage: He gets to his feet with some difficulty and then faces her .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Breathing heavily .Enid ——

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Guilelessly .Yes ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Putting his heels together and bowing to her .If you would permid me to be your bangker during your sday at Ostend — four weegs ——

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Karl ——

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: I should be mosd gradified .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Going to him .I could n't . Such an obligation !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Bowing again .On my side .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Giving him her hands .Of course , I 'd defray my travelling expenses , and tips and incidentals ——

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Raising her hands to his lips .Ah !——

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Not a penny of those should fall on you .Withdrawing her hands quickly and backing away from him .H'sh !

div.stage: STIDULPH enters at the door on the left and again wanders to the counter .

lg.l: You 're missing a very pretty waltz , Miss

lg.stage: Going to the door on the left , VON RETTENMAYER following her .
lg.l: I was just saying so to the Baron .

div.stage: ENID and VON RETTENMAYER disappear . STIDULPH lights his cigarette and is leaving the counter when GABRIELLE and DE CASTRO enter at the right-hand door at the back , DE CASTRO looking exceedingly sulky .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: To GABRIELLE and DE CASTRO .Ah , Miss Kato ; ah , Sam ! A pleasant party , eh ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Shortly .Yeth .STIDULPH goes out at the right-hand door at the back . DE CASTRO crosses to the left and then turns to GABRIELLE .Dam pleathant party !

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Dolefully .Well , do n't make a scene .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Thene ! I 'm not makin ’ a thene . Walkin ’ away from me in the middle of a danthe and leavin ’ me thtandin ’ thtarin ’ after you like a detherted child ! You 're makin ’ the thene !

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: I 'm very sorry .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: I 'm jutht ath good a waltzther ath anyone here , and better than motht .Waving his arms .If you 're tired of me , announthe the fact quietly . Do n't go and wipe your bootth on me in public , becauthe that hurtth my pride .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: With a little twist of her body .I can n't do more than apologise . First time I 've ever done that to a man .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Coming to her , mollified .I do n't athk it , Gabth ; I do n't athk it . All I athk ——

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Sitting on the nearer settee in the centre .If I 'm rude , it 's owing to my low spirits . I 'm so shockingly low-spirited .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: I know you are , and I make allowanthes for yer . I repeat , all I athk ——

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Gazing at vacancy .Mine 's a strange nature . On the stage , I 'm liveliness itself ——!

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: A perfect little lump o ’ talent ! I 've been tellin ’ Carlton tho — perthuadin ’ him to introduthe an extra thong for you in Act Two .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Looking at DE CASTRO .You have ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Yeth .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Did he promise to think it over ?

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Hith exthact wordth !

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: With a hollow laugh .Ha , ha , ha !Resuming her former attitude .As I was remarking , I 'm a mass of inconsistency . On the stage the embodiment of elfish fun ——

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: That wath in the Mail .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Nodding .In the Mail . Off the stage , I 'm a sufferer from what 's called the artistic temperature — no — temperament ——

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Uncomfortably , patting her shoulder .Po ’ little girl ; po ’ little girl !

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Her melancholy increasing .Sometimes I 've an idea that if I had a motor-car of my own I should feel easier and happier .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: With a change of tone .What d'ye mean — motor-car of yer own ? Mine'th alwayth at your dithpothal , ith n't it ?

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Shaking her head .That 's not the same thing . Whenever I have yours out , I 'm weighed down by a sense of borrowing .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Well , if I gave you a new car , you 'd be weighed down by a thenthe of my havin ’ paid for it .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: At first I should , but not for long . Seeing my family crest on the door-panels , instead of your monogram , ‘ ud help me to forget you 'd had anything to do with it .Gloomily .Of course , it ‘ ud only be an experiment . It might cheer me up , or it might n't .

div.stage: The music ceases . A waiter carrying a tray enters at the door on the left , goes behind the counter , and mixes some drinks .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: After a pause , loosening his collar — in a low voice .Here ! We 'd better dithcuth thith experiment .Glancing over his shoulder at the waiter .Let'th come and thit in the pit .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Rising .I can n't argue ; my head 's too bad for that .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Leading her to the double-door .I do n't want to argue ; I thimply want to arrive at an underthtandin ’ . Thuppothin ’ I buy you a car , am I to be made an arth of at the nexth danthe we happen to meet at — yeth or no ?——

div.stage: They go out on to the landing and disappear as FULKERSON hurries in at the right-hand door at the back . His eyes are rather glassy and his utterance is a little thick .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: To the waiter , joining him behind the counter .Hi ! Wake up , there ! Gla'sodawa ' erf'misspirch ' nth'stage .Distinctly .Misspirch — on th'stage — gla ’ — sodawa'er . I 'll have a whiskey . Wh'sthwhiskey ? Which — is — the — whiskey ? Than'g .Pouring some whiskey into a tumbler .You take sodaw'er t ’ Misspirch ; I 'll mix m'own whiskey . Loo ’ sharp , sodaw'er Misspirch .The waiter goes out with the drinks and FULKERSON , glass in hand , comes to the nearer side of the counter . He swallows his drink greedily , singing to himself between the gulps .“ Oh , the gals ! Oh , the gals ! I am awfully fond of the gals !Putting his empty glass upon the counter and making for the door on the left .Be they ebon or blond , Of the gals I am fond ; I am dreadfully fond of the gals ! ”

div.stage: He vanishes as FARNCOMBE and LILY enter at the right-hand door at the back . There is an air of constraint and uneasiness about the girl . She comes to the nearer settee in the centre and again picks up her bouquet . FARNCOMBE follows her . They talk in subdued voices and with frequent pauses .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Another ice ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rearranging a rose , almost inaudibly .No , thanks .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: After a pause .I — I wish I had given you a bouquet instead of a big , ugly basket .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: You — you might have brought it to the theatre , as you have that one , and carried it about with you .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Coldly .I did n't bring this to the theatre .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: No ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I found it with a lot of other flowers at the stage-door . It 's from the gallery boys —looking at him for a moment steadily— and I attach some value to it .

div.stage: The bearded waiter enters at the right-hand door at the back , takes a box of cigars from the counter , and goes out at the door on the left . LILY walks away from FARNCOMBE and seats herself upon the further settee in the centre .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: After the waiter has withdrawn , producing his programme .Number Nine . “ Two Step . Mind the Paint . ”To LILY .Of course , you — you are engaged for this ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: And you , surely ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: No , I — I kept it open , in case — in case ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Decidedly .I dance it with Morrie .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Mr. Cooling ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Morrie Cooling .

lg.stage: After another pause , sitting , behind her , upon the nearer settee .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I wonder whether Mr. Cooling would let you off .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I should n't dream of asking him .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: No , but — may I ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Haughtily .I beg you 'll do nothing of the sort .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Forgive me .

div.stage: There is a further pause and then she turns to him .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Why I spoke so — so sharply to you — was ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: You did n't speak sharply to me .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Was because I 've been very nasty with Morrie — wrote him a furious letter — and I want to make it up to him .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Ah , yes .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I called him a pig , and other things ; I hate myself for it .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: A pig ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Smiling .Still , that 's no reason why I should be nasty with you .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Laughingly .And call me a pig .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Impulsively , kneeling upon the settee so that she may compare her programme with his .Look here ! Fifteen — the last but one . Are you fixed up for Fifteen ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I kept it open — in case ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Merrily .Ha , ha —!Checking herself , severely .I might be able to give you Fifteen .FARNCOMBE scribbles on his programme eagerly .Do n't count on it , please ; but it 's booked to Mr. Fulkerson , and Bertie 's not always to be depended upon at that hour .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Thank you — thank you — thank you .She resumes her seat and he jumps up and goes to her .That reminds me . May I ask who is going to see you home , Miss Parradell ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: See me home ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: It would be an honour that I should — appreciate — more than I can — find words to express .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rising , sternly .I am very much obliged to you .Walking away from him again .I dare say Mr. Roper will see me home — and Mr. de Castro — and Mr . Bland ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Following her , unhappily .I — I hope — I — I hope I have n't offended you .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Not in the least ;in a frigid toneonly I am in the habit of relying on old friends for those little services .

div.stage: STIDULPH enters from the landing and again wanders to the counter and to the cigarettes . The “ Mind the Paint ” air , to the time of a Two Step , is played in the distance .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Bowing to LILY slightly and drawing himself up .Shall I — take you to Mr. Cooling ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With dignity , inclining her head .Will you ?She is putting her hand through his arm when the look upon his face softens her . She drops her voice to a whisper .Have I hurt you ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Oh , I deserve the rebuke .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No , you do n't .Gently .You may leave me at my door , with the others , if it will give you any satisfaction .

div.stage: As they walk to the door on the left , they are met by COOLING .

sp.speaker: COOLING
sp.p: To LILY , breathlessly .Haw ! Here you are !

lg.stage: Leaving FARNCOMBE , her manner altering completely .
Her feet moving to the music .
lg.l: Tra , lal , la ! Tra , lal , la !

sp.speaker: COOLING AND LILY
sp.p: Tra , lal , la ! Tra , lal , la ——!

div.stage: They run out , half dancing .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Calling to FARNCOMBE , who is following them .Lord Farncombe !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Going to him .Will you spare me a moment ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: A little impatiently .Er — certainly .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Laying a shaky hand on FARNCOMBE 'S arm and leading him away from the door .Excuse me for what I 'm going to say to you . I — I know your father — knew him very well years ago — and your mother .With deep feeling .My boy — my dear boy ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Surprised .Colonel ?

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: I — I — I 'm sorry to find you in this set .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Stiffly .What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Do n't be angry with me . I 'm an old man — and an old fool ; but it 's from the fools that the useful lessons are to be learned .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Withdrawing his arm from STIDULPH .I really do n't understand you .

sp.speaker: STIDULPH
sp.p: Try to . Not now — another time ; when this music is n't exciting you , nor these pretty women . Think it out by yourself ! You 're at the beginning of your career , my boy . Remember me — the old fool who 's brought his to a miserable end — and that I cautioned you — cautioned you —!

div.stage: LUIGI hurries in at the door on the left , followed by a waiter carrying a tray , and by the waiter with the beard .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Laughing .He , he , he , he !Behind the counter , preparing drinks .Look out , gentlemen ; you are losing it all . They are having a romp — a fine lark .FARNCOMBE goes out at the door on the left .Make haste , Colonel ; make haste !STIDULPH goes out , slowly , at the right-hand door at the back .Whiskey-and-soda for Mr. Tavish ; liqueur of brandy — Mr. Grimwood .The waiter carrying the tray goes out with the drinks at the door on the left .Ha , ha , ha !Singing to the music .Tra , lal , la ! Tra , lal , la ——!

div.stage: LUIGI is following the waiter who has carried out the tray when the bearded waiter , coming to the nearer settee in the centre , calls to him .

sp.speaker: THE BEARDED WAITER
sp.p: Sitting upon the settee , gruffly .Luigi .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Halting .Eh ?

lg.stage: Taking out a handful of money and selecting some gold from it .
Putting the gold into LUIGI 'S palm .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Oh , you are spoiling them .

sp.speaker: THE BEARDED WAITER
sp.p: Giving some more gold pieces to LUIGI .For you .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: Bowing low .Thank you very much .With a polite grin , as he disposes of the coins in different pockets .Hope you have enjoyed yourself , Captain .

sp.speaker: THE BEARDED WAITER
sp.p: Speaking in the voice of JEYES .Thoroughly .Quietly , between his teeth .Warm work , though !Rising slowly , like a man with stiff joints .I 'll be off now , with your permission .

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: See you at lunch , Captain ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Probably .Nodding .Good-night . Good morning .He slouches away to the door on the left and there stops , listening . There is the sound of people approaching , singing uproariously and shouting and laughing .Hullo !

sp.speaker: LUIGI
sp.p: At his elbow .Ho , ho , ho , ho !

div.stage: LUIGI goes out into the corridor and JEYES retreats behind the counter . The noise increases and presently FULKERSON rushes in , flourishing his arms madly . He is followed by GLYNN and SHIRLEY who are carrying LILY upon their interlocked hands , and by PALK who is helping to support her . Then come HENEAGE and NITA , GRIMWOOD and DAPHNE , TAVISH and FLO , VON RETTENMAYER and ENID , DE CASTRO and GABRIELLE , ROPER and MRS. STIDULPH , FARNCOMBE and JIMMIE , BLAND and EVANGELINE , COOLING and SYBIL , and SMYTHE and OLGA . Singing the chorus of the “ Mind the Paint ” song , and dancing to it wildly , they circle the saloon twice , go out at the right-hand door at the back , return at the door on the left , and finally disappear through the double-door and along the landing . The waiters , who have brought up the rear of the procession , gather , with LUIGI , in the left-hand corner , clapping their hands , and STIDULPH returns , entering at the right-hand door at the back .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Waving her bouquet and shrieking with laughter .Ha , ha , ha , ha ! Do n't drop me ! Do n't drop me !

sp.speaker: HENEAGE AND GRIMWOOD
sp.p: Yelling .Whoop ! Whoop !

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Deliriously , endeavouring to stand upon his head .Wh-o-o-op !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Breaking from the rank and jumping on to the further settee — singing .“ Mind the paint ! Mind the paint ! A girl is not a sinner just because she 's not a saint !—— ”

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha ! You 'll drop me ! Oh ——!

div.stage: As the procession passes out of sight , followed by LUIGI and the waiters , JEYES departs at the door on the left and STIDULPH once more goes to the counter and lights a cigarette .
END OF THE SECOND ACT .

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: The scene is LILY 'S boudoir — a room upon the second floor of her house , adjoining her bedroom . The decorations , though delicate , are gay , with a good deal of pink in them .

In the wall facing the spectator are two doors , one on the left , the other in the centre . The left-hand door opens into the room from the landing , where the staircase is shown ; the centre door admits to the bedroom . In the right-hand wall there are two sash-windows giving a view of the tops of trees growing in a square ; in the opposite wall , the grate hidden by a low , painted screen , is the fireplace .

A prettily designed “ fitment ” runs along the left-hand wall and the further wall , taking in the fireplace and doors as part of its scheme . On either side of the fireplace there is a cupboard with drawers beneath it ; between the door on the left and the door in the centre is a similar cupboard ; and on the right of the centre door , extending to the right-hand wall , there is a wardrobe with sliding doors . The cupboard doors are glazed and curtained in pink silk .

In the middle of the room , a little to the right , there is a large and comfortable settee , and on the left of the settee is a table littered with books , magazines , a scent-atomizer , a small silver-framed mirror , a case of manicure instruments , a box of cigarettes and a match-stand , and other odds and ends . Behind the table there is a fauteuil-stool , and on the right of the table a cosy arm-chair . A second arm-chair stands apart , between the table in the centre and the fireplace .

On the extreme left of the room , on the nearer side of the fireplace , there is a box-ottoman ; on the other side of the room , by the nearer window , are a small writing-table and chair ; standing across the right-hand corner , the key-board towards the further window , are a cottage-piano and a music-stool ; and at the back of the piano there is another small chair , with some soiled gloves upon it .

A quantity of music is heaped untidily on the top of the piano ; one of the wardrobe doors is open , revealing some dresses hanging within ; and the edge of a lace petticoat , with its insertion of coloured ribbon , peeps out from under the carelessly-closed lid of the box-ottoman . Two milliner 's hat-boxes are on the floor by the ottoman , and a pair of satin slippers are lying , one here , one there , under the centre table .
The window-blinds are down but the daylight is seen through them .

div.stage: The door on the left opens and LILY , still carrying her bouquet , enters and makes straight for the windows and draws up the blinds , letting in the clear , morning light . She is followed by ENID , GABRIELLE , DAPHNE , and JIMMIE and they by FARNCOMBE , VON RETTENMAYER , DE CASTRO , ROPER , FULKERSON , and BLAND . They are all pale and haggard , and slightly dishevelled , but everybody seems broad awake except DAPHNE , who is borne down by sleepiness . Some of the men are smoking .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Laying her bouquet upon the table in the centre as she crosses to the windows — to the women .Come in , dears ;drawing up the blind of the nearer windowcome in , boys . Take off your things for a minute .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Whose inebriety has reached the argumentative stage .Working classhes ! Don ’ talk t ’ me ‘ bout th ’ working classhes !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: H'sh ! Shut up , Bertie .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: I 'm s'h ' ick o ’ th ’ ve'y mention o ’ th ’ name — working classhes !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Sit on his head , somebody . We shall wake Ma and the servants .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Taking off her wrap and hanging it up in the wardrobe .Do n't worry ; you wo n't wake my servants . And mother 's bound to hear us ; she sleeps so lightly when I 'm out .

sp.speaker: DAPHNE
sp.p: Gaping violently .Oh-h-h-h !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Clapping her hand over DAPHNE 'S mouth .Manners !

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Depositing his overcoat and hat upon the fauteuil-stool .One ‘ ud ‘ magine th ’ working-man'sh th ’ on'y pershon who ever does day'sh work ! Ridiculush !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER AND BLAND
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Thome truth in what Bertie'th thayin ’ , though . For inthtanthe ——

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: With great disgust .Br'ish workinghYpppHeNman !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: By Jove , yes ! When I think o ’ the work Mr. Lionel Hesketh Roper manages to dispose of in the course of a day ——!

div.stage: VON RETTENMAYER and DE CASTRO have placed their overcoats and hats upon the chair at the back of the piano and FARNCOMBE , BLAND , and ROPER have piled theirs on the arm-chair on the left . ENID and GABRIELLE throw their wraps upon the settee , DAPHNE drops hers upon the box-ottoman , and JIMMIE puts hers over the arm of the chair by the centre table .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To everybody .I 'll just run upstairs and tell mother that all 's serene .She goes to the door on the left ; FARNCOMBE , BLAND , and ROPER get in each other 's way in their desire to open it for her .If any of you want a drink , you must hunt for it yourselves in the dining-room .To ROPER .You play host , Uncle Lal .

div.stage: She disappears , turning to the left and ascending the stairs .

lg.l: Now , then , give your orders , gents !
Ladies , do n't all speak at once .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Making for the door .I 'll have sma ’ whiskeyan ’ soda .

div.stage: He goes along the landing and down the stairs .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Following him .No , no ! Bertie ! Bertie ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Seated in the arm-chair by the centre table — to ROPER .Stop it . We 'll have trouble enough to get that boy home as it is .

div.stage: ROPER hurries out after BLAND and FULKERSON . VON RETTENMAYER and DE CASTRO also move to the door .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: To ENID , who is sitting with GABRIELLE on the settee .Enid ——?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: A glass of soda-water .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Same for me , Von .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: To JIMMIE .Jimmie ——?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: No , thanks .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Looking down upon DAPHNE , who has curled herself up on the box-ottoman and is already asleep — sentimentally .Baby — baby ——

sp.speaker: DAPHNE
sp.p: Half sighing , half moaning .Ah-h-h-h !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To VON RETTENMAYER .Do n't disturb her . Let her have her snooze in peace .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Still contemplating DAPHNE .Shall I bring you your boddle , you preddy liddle baby ?

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Annoyed .Do n't be an idiot , Karl .To DE CASTRO , who is talking to FARNCOMBE .Sam , will you fetch me some soda-water ?

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: To ENID , bestirring himself .I beg bardon .He goes out , with DE CASTRO . ENID has taken the mirror from the table and now looks at herself in it .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: What a sight !To GABRIELLE .I wonder whether Lil would mind me going into her bedroom ?

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Taking the mirror from ENID .Of course she would n't .Viewing herself with dismay .Oh , I 'm yellower than you !

div.stage: She jumps up , throwing the mirror upon the settee , and goes to the door in the centre . ENID follows her and the two girls open the door narrowly and withdraw . JIMMIE rises and picks up the mirror .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: With one knee upon the settee , surveying herself .Ugh , you lovely creature !Glancing at FARNCOMBE as she readjusts a comb , and finding that he is gazing at her earnestly .Turn your face to the wall , please ; I 'm about to use my puff .

div.stage: Suddenly , with rapid movements , he shuts the door on the left , gives a quick look at DAPHNE , assures himself that the centre door is closed , and comes to JIMMIE . She stares at him in astonishment .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Standing at the back of the settee — in a low voice .Miss Birch , you 're Miss Parradell 's friend — her great friend . Will you be a friend of mine too , and do me a service ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Startled .It — it all depends ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Beg her to allow me to remain behind , with you , for a few minutes after the others have gone .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Remain — you and I ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: And then , if she will , will you wait in the next room while I speak to her ? Miss Birch , I — I must speak to her .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: W-w-would n't — to-morrow ——?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: It is to-morrow now . It 's day .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Dropping her eyes .She 's tired .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Five minutes — no longer .Entreatingly .Wo n't you try to arrange it for me ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Pursing her lips .H 'm ! I 'd stay ; delighted .Demurely .It does n't matter how tired I feel .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Contritely .I 'm a brute !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: But I really think the arranging is your job , Lord Farncombe .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I know I should make a bungle of it with all these people round me , and attract attention . You 're clever .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Raising her eyes to his , abruptly .Look here ! Do I guess correctly ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: What ——?

div.stage: She pulls him towards her and whispers into his ear . He nods . She whispers again , breathlessly , and then releases him .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Eh ? Eh ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Drawing back and facing her , firmly .Yes .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Walking away , in a flutter .Oh ! Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: You 'll help me ?She pauses , deliberating .You 'll help me ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Returning to him , with an air of prudence .I tell you what I will do .Pointing to the writing-table .Scribble her a note — a line — and I 'll give it to her . That wo n't attract attention . I 've no objection to do that for you . Hurry up !He sits at the writing-table and searches for writing materials .In the drawer .He opens a drawer and takes out a sheet of note-paper . Standing at the other side of the table , she selects a pen and hands it to him .A “ J ” suit you ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Taking the pen from her .What shall I say ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Ho , ho ! Well , I never !He writes .Oh , but it is n't exactly a love-letter , is it ? Simply say — what was the expression you used just now ?— “ will you allow me to remain behind for a few minutes with Miss Birch after the others have gone ? ”

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Writing .Thank you .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: With a little wriggle .Call me Jimmie if you like .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Knitting her brow thoughtfully .I suppose you ought to give her an inkling , though — the merest hint — of the reason , ought n't you ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Looking up .Ought I ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Well , you do n't want her to think it 's only to chat about the weather ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: For heaven 's sake , do n't chaff me !writing“ — after the others have gone ? ”Biting his pen .How would this do ? “ I know I am presuming a lot , but I — I can n't leave you — I can n't leave you till I — till I have asked you — till I have asked you the most important question a man can put to a woman . ”

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Oh , but that 's ideal !GABRIELLE reappears .Dash these girls !To GABRIELLE , whose complexion is much improved .Lord Farncombe is writing me out a remedy for freckles . Is n't it sweet of him ?

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Mournfully .Freckles ! If you want to see a martyr to freckles , knock at my door .

div.stage: ENID returns , with lips that are a little too red , as VON RETTENMAYER and DE CASTRO re-enter at the door on the left . They leave the door open . VON RETTENMAYER is carrying a syphon of soda-water and DE CASTRO two tumblers . The men put the syphon and tumblers on the centre table and VON RETTENMAYER fills the glasses and he and DE CASTRO hand them to ENID and GABRIELLE .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: To ENID and GABRIELLE .I hobe we haf nod kepd you waiding .

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Bertie'th been makin ’ himthelf a reg'lar nuithanthe downthairth .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Poor Bertie ! Pity he has this little failing .

lg.l: Yes , there 's not a nicer boy in London than

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Flieth to hith head tho !

div.stage: The four continue talking . JIMMIE has gone back to FARNCOMBE , who is still writing , and is watching him impatiently .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE , under her breath .Do be quick !

div.stage: Hastily he blots his note and folds it . BLAND , FULKERSON , and ROPER appear on the landing , issuing from the staircase , and there they are joined by LILY , who comes down the stairs .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: On the landing , to LILY , indignantly .Lirry — Misspa'dell ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE .Here she is !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To FULKERSON .Now , then ; have it out with Lily !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: What 's wrong ?

div.stage: FARNCOMBE rises and slips his note into JIMMIE 'S hand .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: To LILY .Mosht unjusht'fiable treatmen ’ ‘ n th ’ part ‘ f these gen'lemen !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Listening , with the others at the centre table , to what is going on upon the landing .Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE , over her shoulder .Good luck !

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: To LILY .The youth is irate with us for cutting off supplies .

div.stage: LILY enters with FULKERSON ; ROPER and BLAND following . BLAND strolls over to the piano , laughing .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: To LILY .M ’ argumen ’ is this . When a gen'leman ' sh invited b ’ th ’ lady ‘ f th ’ house t ’ partake ‘ f refreshmen ’ ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To FULKERSON .Be quiet , Bertie , or I 'll box your ears .Joining the group at the centre table .Ho , ho ! I 've had such a wigging for asking you up . Mother says we girls 'll look as ugly as sin on the stage to-night .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: So we shall — hags .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Sitting in the arm-chair by the centre table .I feel as fresh as paint .To GABRIELLE .Give me a sip .

div.stage: DE CASTRO hands GABRIELLE 'S glass to LILY .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Gazing at DAPHNE stupidly and singing to himself .“ Oh , the gals ! Oh , the gals ! I am awfully fond of the gals !—— ”

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER , ROPER , DE CASTRO , ENID AND GABRIELLE
sp.p: Chiming in with FULKERSON lightly .“ Be they ebon or blond , Of the gals I am fond ;—— ” ! Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: H'sh , h'sh ! Ma 's quite right .Seating himself at the piano .One more turn and then let 's clear out .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Jumping up .Hurrah !To ROPER , as BLAND runs his hands over the key-board .Shut the door , Uncle Lal .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Aha ! One more durn !To ENID .Enid ——!

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Singing .“ I am dreadfully fond of the gals ! ”

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Closing the door .Choose your partners , gents !Very softly BLAND plays the melody of a languorous song and instantly VON RETTENMAYER and ENID and DE CASTRO and GABRIELLE dance to it — VON RETTENMAYER and ENID at the back , DE CASTRO and GABRIELLE near the piano .Jimmie ——!

div.stage: JIMMIE passes LILY to go to ROPER . As she does so , she presses FARNCOMBE 'S note into LILY 'S palm .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To LILY , in a whisper .Rat-tat , says the postman !Catching hold of ROPER and swinging him round .La , ra , ral , la ——!

lg.stage: To FARNCOMBE , who is standing by the writing-table .

div.stage: FARNCOMBE goes to her and they dance together .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: To DAPHNE , tapping her on the shoulder .Missdure , may I have th ’ grea ’ pleasure ——?Shaking her .Missdure — Missdure ——

sp.speaker: DAPHNE
sp.p: Starting up .Oh !Looking round wildly .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Dancing with her .Pray ‘ xcuse th ’ absence ‘ f gloves .

sp.speaker: DAPHNE
sp.p: Faintly .Oh ! Oh , I — I thought I 'd gone to bed !With their hands on each other 's shoulders , the couples , swaying from side to side , half sing , half murmur , the refrain of the song .If you would only , only love me ; If you would merely , merely say , Wait but a little , little for me , I will be yours , be yours some day !

div.stage: The refrain is repeated , the dancers droning to it with a , buzzing sound , and then BLAND returns to the melody .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: As she dances , recollecting the note she is holding and opening it .What 's this ?Reading the note , her arm resting upon FARNCOMBE 'S shoulder .“ Dear Miss Parradell ....glancing at the signatureFarncombe ” !To FARNCOMBE .From you !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Reading .“ Will you allow me to ——? ”

div.stage: She reads to the end silently , and then she stops dancing and they stand for a moment looking confusedly at each other . Then , with an expressionless face , she slips the note into her dress and they dance again , singing the refrain as before .

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: At the finish , shutting down the lid of the piano and rising .Ladies and gentlemen , the festivities connected with Miss Parradell 's birthday are over .Leaving the piano .Our lives will now resume their normal , serious course .

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Regretfully .Ah-h-h-h !

div.stage: The ladies put on their wraps , the men their overcoats , and there is a great deal of stir and chatter . DE CASTRO assists GABRIELLE ; VON RETTENMAYER , ENID ; FULKERSON , DAPHNE ; and FARNCOMBE , JIMMIE . LILY joins in the talk and bustle with forced animation . JIMMIE and FARNCOMBE glance at her , and then , inquiringly , at one another .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Putting on his overcoat with BLAND 'S help .Well , nobody can say the affair has n't been a brilliant success ; that 's one comfort .

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Would n't be true if they did .To DE CASTRO , irritably .You 've got it inside-out .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To ENID and GABRIELLE , kneeling upon the settee .Ah , yes , have n't we had a splendid , splendid time !

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: Splendid !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: A gharming pardy !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Abtholutely A 1 !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Singing .“ Venus , seinen Nacken beut Dir Dein Sklave , dienstbereit ! ”

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Running to ROPER and seizing his hands .A vote of thanks to Lal for his share in getting it up !

sp.speaker: BLAND
sp.p: Slapping ROPER on the back .Bravo , Lal !

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE OTHERS
sp.p: Bravo , Lal !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Walking about .And to Carlton ! Bravo , Carlton !

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE OTHERS
sp.p: Bravo , Carlton ! Bravo , Smythe !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: Putting on his overcoat .Do n't forget Morrie Coolin ’ !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No , do n't forget Morrie . Dear old Morrie !

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE OTHERS
sp.p: Bravo , Morrie !

sp.speaker: DE CASTRO
sp.p: There hath n't been a hitch from thtart to finish , in fact .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: At the nearer side of the table again .Not a hitch .

sp.speaker: FULKERSON
sp.p: Remembering his grievance .I beg yo ’ par'n — no ’ a ‘ itch !In difficulties with his overcoat .When a gen'leman ' sh invited b ’ th ’ lady ‘ f th ’ house t ’ partake ‘ f some refreshmen ’ ——

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE OTHERS
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: GABRIELLE
sp.p: Coming to LILY and kissing her .So long , dear .

div.stage: ENID , DAPHNE , and JIMMIE also come to LILY , who embraces them demonstratively , and the men follow .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To the girls .Ta-ta ; ta-ta ; ta-ta ! I wo n't come down .

sp.speaker: ENID
sp.p: No , no ; we 'll let ourselves out .Leaving LILY .Till to-night !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Till to-night !Shaking hands with the men .Ta-ta ; ta-ta ; ta-ta !

sp.speaker: THE MEN
sp.p: Ta-ta ! Ta-ta ! Ta-ta !

sp.speaker: VON RETTENMAYER
sp.p: Kissing her hand slyly .Goddess !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To BLAND , in a whisper .Take care of Bertie .Everybody moves to the door , except LILY who remains standing in the middle of the room . Some are on the landing , some in the doorway , when she calls to ROPER and JIMMIE .Uncle Lal ! Jimmie ! I want to speak to you two for a second .ROPER and JIMMIE detach themselves from the rest and return .Oh — and Lord Farncombe !FARNCOMBE also returns and LILY , passing him , goes on to the landing and mixes with the others .Be off ; Lord Farncombe and Lal will look after Jimmie . Vincent , you close the front-door . No noise ! Au revoir , mes enfants !She watches them descend the stairs and , her manner softening , comes back into the room .Lord Farncombe wants to have a quiet talk with me , Uncle Lal — about — about something , and he 's asked me to let him remain behind with Jimmie for a few minutes .To JIMMIE .But there 's no necessity for you to wait , dear .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Do n't consider me .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: But I do . Go upstairs and tell mother that Lord Farncombe 's with me . Say I promise he sha n't stay long .To ROPER .You 'll take Jimmie home , wo n't you , Lal ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: His eyes bolting .W-w-with pleasure .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To JIMMIE .I shall see you again later in the day , perhaps ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Rather !Throwing her arms round LILY 'S neck and pressing her cheek to LILY 'S .Rather !To ROPER , significantly .Sit in the hall till I 'm ready .

div.stage: She runs out on to the landing , pausing at the door to bestow a parting nod and a smile upon FARNCOMBE , and ascends the stairs .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: In a state of great excitement and exhilaration — to LILY .Yes , yes , I wo n't keep you and —winking at her and jerking his head in FARNCOMBE 'S directionfrom your tête-à-tête .Patting her face gleefully .Ha , ha , ha , ha !Taking her hand , his own quivering .Lil , Uncle Lal you call me , but I 've always felt more like a parent towards you — acted as such , hey ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Y-y-yes , Lal .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: And any happiness that befalls you — any happiness that befalls you —chokingI 'll leave it there . God bless yer ; God bless yer !bustling over to FARNCOMBE who , his hat in his hand , his overcoat on his arm , is standing near the pianoand God bless you , my lad !incoherentlyI 'm proud — proud to have the honour — and to have been the means of — the means of —wringing FARNCOMBE 'S handGod bless you both !He goes to the door and there finds LILY .I — I — I — I 'll drop in by-and-by and — and — and inquire after you , my pet .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Faintly .All right , Lal .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Patting her face again .Ha , ha , ha , ha !With a hop .Wurrr-roo ! Stand away from the lift ; no more passengers this journey !

div.stage: He waves to FARNCOMBE gaily and departs , closing the door . There is a short silence and then FARNCOMBE places his hat and overcoat upon the chair by the piano and turns to LILY .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: In a low voice .It 's awfully kind and gracious of you to have granted my request , and frightfully selfish of me to have made it . I deserve to be kicked .

lg.stage: Slowly advancing to the table in the centre — avoiding his gaze .
lg.l: Is — is Jimmie aware of precisely what 's in your note ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Y-y-yes .Drawing nearer to her .I hope you wo n't be angry with me for confiding in her . You see , I — I ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: At the further side of the table , fingering one of the objects upon it .And she 'll confide in Uncle Lal .Shrugging her shoulders .Oh , but dear old Lal appears to have summed up the situation pretty accurately as it is .With an artificial little laugh .Ha , ha , ha ! Well , I 'm afraid they 'll be horribly disappointed , poor wretches .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Blankly .Disap-pointed ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Raising her eyes to his and shaking her head at him .You — you silly boy !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Coming to her quickly .Ah , please — please do n't take that tone with me . I 'm no boy . And I 'm simply mad about you . If you do n't marry me , I — I — I 'm done for .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: H'sh ! Nonsense ; not you !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: It 's true . Life 'll be over for me from that moment , if you refuse to marry me .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Mockingly .Over !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Oh , love is all on my side at present , naturally ; but , as God hears me , it 'll be no fault of mine if you do n't grow to love me in time .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Listen ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I 'll worship you — worship you . I do worship you !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: H'sh ! Lord Farncombe ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Eddie ! Wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Certainly not .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Do ! Eddie ! Eddie !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Eddie , then ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Ah ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Sit down a minute .She goes to the settee and sits there , somewhat ruffled , and he moves to the arm-chair by the centre table and also sits , his elbows on his knees , bending towards her . She pushes her hair back from her brow impatiently , as if vexed with herself .Lord Farncombe — Eddie — for how long have you known me ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: What does it matter ? I — I admit ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Reckoning our acquaintance from last week — from the afternoon Bertie brought you here , when we scarcely spoke to one another — you have n't known me for as many days as you can count on your fingers .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I 've watched you — watched you in the theatre ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: On the stage ! Ho , ho ! Oh , you — but I must n't call you silly boy again , must I ! And what do you know of me , apart from the glimpse you 've had of me off the stage , and my being a shining light at the Pandora ? What do you know of my — what 's the word ?— origin — where and what I 've sprung from ; how I was reared ; how much education I 've received ; how much I 've contrived to pick up of the way to behave in perlite society ? You can judge from poor mother , if from nothing else , that I come from humble beginnings . Yes , but how humble you could n't dream ,making a grimacenot after a supper of raw carrots !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Do you think I care how humble your beginnings were ! What I do know — what I am sure about — is that you 're good — and beautiful — and — and — and gifted — and — and —leaning his head on his handsoh , I can n't describe you ; you 're — you 're — to me , you 're perfect .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: After a pause , looking at him with blinking eyelids .You — you dear !He raises his head . She changes her tone instantly .Merci ; yes , perfect , pour le moment . Hear my French !Taking the box of cigarettes from the table .Have a cigarette ? Do n't get up .She tosses him a cigarette and he catches it .My name 's printed on them — “ Lily . ”Lighting a cigarette .Is n't it chic !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Producing his cigarette case and exchanging her cigarette for one of his own .I 'll never smoke that .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Pushing the match-stand towards him .Stoopid ! Now , attend to me . What do you say to a tiny provision shop in Kennington , over the water ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Was that ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Nodding .H 'm ; that was my start in the world . Father kept a small shop in Kennington — Gladwin Street , near the Oval . We sold groceries , and butter and eggs and cheese , and pickled-pork and paraffin . I was born there — on the second floor ; and in Gladwin Street I lived till I was fourteen . Then father smashed , through the Stores cutting into our little trade . Well , hardly smashed ; that 's too imposing . The business just faded , and one morning we did n't bother to take the shutters down . Then , after a while , father got a starvation berth — eighteen shillings a week !— at a wholesale bacon warehouse — Price and Moseley 's — still over the water ; and I earned an extra five at a place in the Westminster Bridge Road , for pasting the gilt edges on to passe-partouts from nine a. m. till six in the evening .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: His head bowed again .Great heavens !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Not a syllable against the passe-partouts ! They were the making of me . It was the passe-partouts that brought me and Tedder together .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Tedder . In the house where I worked , a man of the name of Tedder — Ambrose Tedder — taught dancing — stage dancing — “ Tedder 's Academy of Saltatory Art ” — and every time I passed Tedder 's door , and heard his violin or piano , and the sound of the pupils ’ feet , I —!Breaking off and throwing herself back .Oh , lor ’ , if once I ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Go on ; go on .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Well , ultimately Tedder took me and trained me — did it for nix — for what he hoped to get out of me in the future . Ah , and he has n't lost over me — poor old Ambrose ! He collared a third of my salary for ever so long ; and now that the old chap 's rheumaticky and worn out , I — oh , it 's not worth mentioning .Jumping up and walking away .My stars , he could teach , could Tedder ! I began by going to him for the last twenty minutes of my dinner-hour . He wanted to stop that , because it was bad for me , he said , to practise on a full — a full —! Ha , ha , ha ! On a full —!Behind the table , resting her two hands upon it and shaking with laughter .Ho , ho , ho ! As if I ever had — in those days ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Writhing .Ah , do n't — do n't ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Brushing the tears from her eyes .I was a pupil of Tedder 's for twelve months , and then he got me on at the Canterbury ; and from the Canterbury I went to Gatti 's , and from Gatti 's to the Lane , for a few lines in the pantomime and an understudy — my first appearance in the West End —singing“ Oh , the West End is the best end ! ” — and from there I went to the old Strand , and there Morrie Cooling spotted me , and that led to me being engaged at the Pandora , where I ate my heart out , doing next to nothing , for two whole years . Then came the production of The Duchess of Brixton , and it was in The Duchess — thanks to Vincent Bland — that I sang the “ Mind the Paint ” song . He believed in me , did Vincent ; he saw I was fit for something more than just prancing about , and airing my ankles , in a gay frock . By Jupiter , how he fought for me ; how he fought for me , up to the final rehearsal ! And to this day , whenever I indulge in a prayer , you bet Vincent Bland has a paragraph all to himself in it !Checking herself and coming to FARNCOMBE .Oh , but — I need n't inflict quite so much of my biography on you , need I ?He rises .Sorry . I merely wanted to tell you enough to show you — to show you ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Close to her , gazing into her eyes .To show me what a — what a marvel you are !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Pleased .Ha , ha ! Oh , I 'm not chucking mud at myself really . Why should I ! Many a woman ‘ ud feel as vain as a peacock in my shoes . Fancy ! From the shop in Gladwin Street to —with a gestureto this ! And from Tedder 's stuffy room in the Westminster Bridge Road to the stage of the Pandora , as principal girl !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Tenderly .Wonderful !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Carried away by her narration and putting her hands upon his shoulders familiarly .Yes , and all the schooling I 've ever had , Eddie , was at a cheap , frowsy day-school in Kennington , with a tribe of other common , skinny-legged brats . Imagine it !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Taking her hands .I can n't imagine it ; I defy anybody to .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Unthinkingly allowing him to retain her hands .Everything I 've learned since — except my music , and that I owe to Tedder and Vincent — everything I 've learned since , I 've learned by sheer cuteness , from novels , the papers , the theatres , and by keeping my ears open like a cunning little parrot .Softly .Ha , ha ! That 's what I am — a cunning little parrot !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Laughing with her .Ha , ha !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Tossing her head .Ho , I dare say , if I had the opportunity , I could imitate the fine lydies you mix with , so that in less than six months you 'd hardly know the difference between them and me !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Holding her hands to his breast .There is no difference already ; there is none .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Is n't there !Almost nestling up to him .Ah , you should see me in one of my vile tempers .Wistfully .Then — then you would n't —!Becoming conscious of her proximity to him , she backs away and stands rubbing the palms of her hands together in embarrassment .Anyhow — anyhow it is n't my intention to give you a chance of comparing us .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Under his breath .Oh — Miss Parradell ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Collecting herself .No , I — I 'm not going to let you make a fool of yourself over me , if I can help it .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Fool ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Facing him and speaking quietly but firmly .Recollect , however shrewd and apt I may be , and however straight I 've managed to keep myself , still — I 'm only a Pandora girl , and should always be remembered as one by your chums and belongings . Only a Pandora girl . Nothing can alter that , dear boy ; and you must n't — you must n't handicap yourself by hanging me round your neck .

lg.l: I — I should n't be the first of my sort to marry a
“ Pandora girl , ” not by half a dozen or more .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No , but — without wishing to flatter you — I do n't quite put you on a level with Robbie Kinterton , and Glenroy , and Georgie Fawcus , and — that crew .Cheerfully .And so I mean to take care of you — to take care of you for your own sake and for your mammy 's and daddy 's .She turns from him and fetches his hat and coat and gives them to him . He receives them from her with a dazed look .Time 's up .After a silence during which neither stirs .Never mind . You 'll survive it .Another pause .Come along .

div.stage: She passes him , to go to the door on the left . As she does so he flings his hat and coat on to the settee , and clasps her in his arms .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Lily — Lily ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Ah , that 's not fair !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Do n't — do n't send me away like this !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Her hand against his breast .It is n't fair of you !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Say you 'll take time to consider .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I hate you for it !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Ask Roper 's advice — your mother 's ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I 've trusted you !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Ask Miss Birch ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Eddie ! Lord Farncombe ——!He releases her and they confront one another , she panting , he hanging his head guiltily .W-w-well , I — I have been mistaken in you .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: In despair .I — I ——Turning from her and hitting his temples with his fists .Forgive me . Forgive me .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Ha ! I — I thought you were such a quiet , bashful fellow .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Forgive me . Forgive me .

div.stage: She wavers and then slowly approaches him .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Gently .Do n't — do n't fret about it . I forgive you .Touching his arm with her finger-tips .I 'm to blame .Drawing a deep breath .All those dances ——!

div.stage: He seizes her hand and kisses it passionately .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I may see you again ? I may see you again ? Lily — Lily —! Lily ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a whisper , averting her head .N-no — we 'd better not ——There is a low but distinct knocking at the door on the left . She withdraws her hand and they look at each other , he inquiringly , she with a calm face . The knocking is repeated .Mother .She goes to the door and speaks with her mouth close to it .That you , mother ?She listens for a reply and again the knocking is heard .Who is it ?She opens the door . JEYES is outside .Nicko !JEYES comes into the room . He has rid himself of his wig and beard and is wearing an overcoat buttoned up to his chin and a cap drawn down to his brows . His face is white and his jaws are set determinedly .How — how have you got in ?He produces a bunch of keys and grimly displays a latch-key .Oh — oh ——!Pulling off his cap , JEYES advances to the table in the centre , glaring at FARNCOMBE . LILY closes the door sharply and also advances , speaking volubly to FARNCOMBE as she comes forward .Captain Jeyes is in the habit of bringing me home from the theatre after my work ; and a long while ago I gave him a latch-key to carry on his key-ring , so that he could let me into my house whenever I 'd forgotten my own key . He has n't the slightest right to use it at any other time ; nobody knows that better than he does . It 's a confounded liberty !To JEYES , hotly .What are you doing here at all at this hour of the morning ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: After an expressive glance at FARNCOMBE .An odd question , in the circumstances .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Answer me !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Keeping an eye on you .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Spying on me !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: On you —jerking his head towards FARNCOMBEand ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: How dare you !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I 've been at it all night .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: All night !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Yes ; I was in the theatre while you were supping and dancing .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: You were !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I meant to be there . You did your best to stop it ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: That 's a lie !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: So that you could enjoy yourself thoroughly —glancing at FARNCOMBE againwith ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: A lie !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I did n't leave till past three . You and —with another motion of the head towards FARNCOMBEhad just had your fifth dance together , and they were hauling you round the building .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Where were you ? Who ——?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Excuse me ; that 's my business . Then I went back to Jermyn Street , and it suddenly struck me I 'd like to see how your escort was composed .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: You 've been watching outside ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Since a quarter-to-four — under the portico at the corner .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Contemptuously .You ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Yes , but , by God , I was n't quite prepared for this !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: This !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Cramming his cap into his overcoat-pocket and coming to FARNCOMBE .What the hell 's your game ? You 've got some accommodating friends , both of you , in that blackguard Roper and that slut Jimmie Birch !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh —!Approaching JEYES with clenched fists .Ah , you cur ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Holding up his hand to her appealingly .Miss Parradell ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To JEYES .You cur ! Mother 's been told that Lord Farncombe 's with me . I sent Jimmie up to tell her .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Where is your mother ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In bed , of course .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Snoring ! Ha , ha , ha ! Faugh , there 's an ugly name , my girl , for such mothers as yours !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Ah —!Raising her fist .Ah-h-h-h ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Miss Parradell ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Restraining herself with difficulty and pacing the room .Oh , the cur ! The cur ! The cur !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: To JEYES , looking at him steadily .Captain Jeyes ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: The low cur !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Captain Jeyes , do you happen to know where I lodge ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: No ; I do n't know where your sty is .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: St. James 's Place — forty-seven . I shall be in at twelve o'clock .Picking up his hat and overcoat .From the tone this gentleman adopts , Miss Parradell , I assume that he considers himself entitled to concern himself in your affairs .Moving over to the left where LILY joins him .Perhaps it will make it easier for you if I ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Clutching his arm .Ah , I 'm so indignant , Eddie ! I — I — I ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Eddie ! Eddie !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Turning upon JEYES in a fury .Yes , you cad — Eddie , Eddie , EDDIE ! You cad ! You sneak ! You idler ! You waster ! I 've stood it long enough . This is the last straw ! I 've done with you ! I 'm sick to death of you ! How I 've tolerated you all these years is a mystery to me ! After this , get out of my sight and never show yourself to me again !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Grasping her wrist , fiercely .Lily ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Wrenching herself free .What !Losing control over herself utterly .You 'll spy on me , will you , you shabby loafer ! You 'll peep at me while I 'm eating my supper , and count the dances I choose to give that boy over there , will you ! And then you 'll break into my house , and insult my friends behind their backs , and insinuate foul things against my poor old mother — you damned coward !— and against me ,pointing to FARNCOMBEand him ! Why , you 're not fit to black his boots , and you never were — never — you — you — you scum ! Here !Taking FARNCOMBE 'S note from her bosom and thrusting it at JEYES .Read that !Sitting in the arm-chair by the centre table .Read it ! Read it ! Read it !JEYES reads to himself .Out loud !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Mumbling .“ Dear Miss Parradell . Will you allow me ——? ”

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Louder !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: “ Will you allow me to remain behind for a few minutes with Miss Jimmie after the others have gone ? I know I am presuming a lot , but I cannot leave you till I have asked you the most important question a man can put to a woman . Farncombe . ”

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Breathless .Written here — on my note-paper — while I was out of the room ! It came on me like a thunder-clap ! Ah ! Ah ! Ah !JEYES sits upon the settee , staring at the carpet .And Morrie Cooling and Lal will tell you that I had n't a notion that Lord Farncombe was to be at the supper last night , or any of the boys ; not a notion . I blackguarded ‘ em both for deceiving me , and causing me to deceive you .Taking the scent-atomizer from the table and spraying her face with it .Now ! What have you to say now ! Ah ! Ah ! Ah !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Huskily .Why — why the devil did you let Jimmie go ? Why did you let her go ? It was knowing that you and Farncombe were alone that — that made me ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh , if I 'd suspected that a private detective was hovering around , I 'd have kept the whole lot of my friends ! As it was , Jimmie was looking dead , and —!in disdain .Pah !

div.stage: There is a pause and then JEYES sits upright and draws his hand wearily across his eyes .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: To LILY .Well , I — I beg your pardon .LILY continues to spray herself energetically .I 'm not so completely scum as not to see that I ought to beg your pardon .Humbly .I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Softening by degrees .You — you drive me mad sometimes — positively frantic !

lg.l: I hope you 'll accept my apologies . I offer them unreservedly .

div.stage: FARNCOMBE bows , somewhat stiffly .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To JEYES , protruding her lower lip .I — I did n't mean half I said , Nicko ; I did n't mean half of it .Eyeing FARNCOMBE askance as she replaces the atomizer .And I — I 'm ashamed of myself for losing my self-control as I did .There is another pause and then JEYES gets to his feet and silently returns the note to LILY . She looks up at him piteously and puts the note back into her bosom . Then he takes out his key-ring , removes the latch key from it , and throws the key on to the table . Having done this , he drags his cap from his pocket and makes for the door on the left . As he passes LILY , she rises and gently plucks at his sleeve .Nicko — Nicko ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: In a thick voice .Eh ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Wo n't you — wo n't you give Lord Farncombe — some explanation ——?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Explanation ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Of the sort of terms we 've been on , you and I , He — he must be — rather puzzled —turning away to the table .Oh , it 's due to you as well as to me !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Dully .Just as you please .With a hard laugh .Ho , ho ! Yes , perhaps it is due to me that he should learn a little more about me than he 's been able to gather from personal observation — and from your eloquent but summary description .Under his breath , screwing up his cap .Idler — waster — loafer ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Penitently .Nicko !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE , quietly .Oh , it 's a true bill , Farncombe . And yet , a very few years back — she wo n't dispute it — I was one of the smartest chaps going , good at my job , with prospects as rosy as any man 's in my regiment . There was n't a cloud the size of your hand , apparently , in my particular bit of sky at the time I speak of ; not a speck ! Then I met this young lady , and —pointing to the box-ottomanwell , since we 're in for it ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Oh , Captain Jeyes ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: No , no ; she wishes you to understand the exact nature of the friendship between her and me . I 'm obeying instructions .FARNCOMBE sits on the ottoman , nursing his hat and overcoat . Then JEYES sits in the arm-chair by the centre table , first turning the chair so that it faces FARNCOMBE .Farncombe , I was under thirty , and still a subaltern , when I made Miss Parradell 's acquaintance . Like most of my pals , I was spending my nights , whenever I could get away from Aldershot , in the stalls at the Pandora — much the same as you 've been doing recently , and as a certain class of young man 'll go on doing as long as the Pandora , and similar shops , continue to flourish . Ha ! How honoured we felt , we men , in those days , at knowing some of the Pandora girls , and having the privilege of supping ‘ em and standing ‘ em dinner on Sunday evenings ! If they 'd been royal princesses we could n't have been more elated .With a gesture .Do n't jump at conclusions . It generally ended there , or with our running into debt at a jeweller 's . We were young , they were beautiful — or we thought ‘ em so ; but the majority of us were n't vicious , any more than the majority of the girls were — though many of ‘ em were mighty calculating . It would have been better for us men if all the girls had been wicked ; the glamour , the infatuation , the folly , would have been sooner over , and one of us at least would have had a different tale to tell .

div.stage: JEYES pauses , gazing at the floor , FARNCOMBE moves impatiently on the ottoman and LILY seats herself upon the settee .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Plaintively .Nicko — Nicko — I merely wanted you to ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Rousing himself and speaking to LILY over his shoulder .Who was it introduced us ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Miss Du Cane — Aggie Du Cane .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Agnes Du Cane . She 's gone under .To LILY .Outside Buckley 's oyster-bar , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Not outside ; in the parlour .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE .Lily had only lately come to the Pandora — a pale-faced slip of a thing .To LILY .Eighteen , were n't you ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Nodding .Eighteen .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I confess I was n't overwhelmingly attracted by her at first ; she was so unlike the rest .Laughing bitterly .Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Weakly .Ha , ha , ha ! Was n't I dowdy !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: But she was humble , and naïve , and confiding ; and my vanity was tickled by her delight at the little treats I gave her , and by her gratitude for a tuppeny-ha'penny present or two . Nobody , I believe , with any pretensions to being a gentleman , had paid her much attention before I arrived on the scene .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a murmur .No ; nobody .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I did n't find out that I was in love with her — you guess it 's a love story , do n't you ?——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Delicately .My dear Captain Jeyes ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I did n't find out that I was neck and heels in love with her until nearly a year afterwards , when my regiment went to the Curragh . That did it — separation ! What I suffered in that hole , thinking of her , starving for her ! In less than three months I was in London again , on leave , and in my old stall at the Pandora . But even then , Farncombe , I had n't your pluck .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Pluck ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: The pluck to snap my fingers at the world and propose marriage to a Pandora girl . Besides , my mother was alive then , and —abruptly , with a wild lookwould you like to know what she used to call these Pandora women , Farncombe ?Bending forward , his hands tightly clenched .She used to call them a menace to society . With their beauty , and their flagrant opportunities for displaying it , they are a living curse , she used to say — a source of constant dread to mothers whose hope it is to see their sons safely mated to modest , maidenly girls of the typical English pattern . She told us once — my brothers and me — frightened as to where we were drifting , that she was one of many mothers who prayed on their knees daily that their boys might be spared from being drawn into the net woven by their own weaknesses and passions — drawn into it by these — these ——!He breaks off , stares about him for a moment , and then rises .Oh , but I ought n't to have repeated this to you . Pardon .Walking away unsteadily .Ho , damned bad taste !Behind the table , supporting himself by leaning upon it .Where was I ? Back from the Curragh !Confused .Yes — yes — and so things went on for a couple o ’ years — I trailing after Lily closer than ever — and at last — at last I did ask her to be my wife .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Who has been listening to JEYES with parted lips and wide-open eyes — appealingly .Do n't ! Do n't , Nicko ; do n't !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Oblivious of her interruption .But I 'd left it too late . The novelty of me had worn off ; she 'd scores of friends by that time ; she 'd made her big hit , and followed it with another , and was the talk o ’ the town . And she 'd money ; she was n't dependent on me any longer for her gloves and her trips and outings !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Her head drooping .Oh ! Oh !Wringing her hands .Oh , that 's beastly of you ; beastly !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: She was kind to me too , in a way — kind and cruel . She did n't want to marry me ; she did n't want to marry anybody ; she was in love with herself , and her success , and what it was bringing her . But she would n't give me the kick . No , she would n't do that ; I had been something to her . And there 's where the kindness came in — and the merciless cruelty .Sitting upon the fauteuil-stool rigidly .God , if only she 'd broken with me then , firmly and finally — if only she 'd broken with me then — she — she might have saved me !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Struggling with her tears .Oh , Nicko , Nicko !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Twelve months ago she did throw me a bone . The regiment was under orders for India , and of course I sent in my papers ; and out of pity , I suppose — and because I was always pestering her — she promised to become engaged to me if I 'd get other work to do . Work ! I wonder whether really she was grinning to herself when she made the stipulation !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh — oh ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Work ! All the spunk , all the energy , had been sapped out of me long before , and even her promise could n't revive it . My search for a berth was n't much more than a sham . At the back of my head I knew very well what I 'd come to . The only work I was capable of was dancing attendance on her , and filling in what remained of the day and night at a rotten restaurant , a Bohemian club , and the bar of the theatre . And that 's been my sole employment for the past year — nothing but that . Pretty , for a man who started life as swimmingly as I did !His voice dying away .Pretty — pretty — pretty — pretty ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: After a profound stillness .I — I do n't think you 've ever — put the case to me — quite so plainly as this , Nicko .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I — I do n't think I 've ever put it quite so plainly — to myself .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Her lip trembling .You — you wo n't believe me ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: What ?

lg.l: I — I 've never fully realised it till now — the harm I 've done you .
I declare to God I 've never realised it till now .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: After a further pause .Ah , well —!With a deep sigh .Ah , well !To FARNCOMBE , resignedly .Farncombe , I — I 'm afraid I 'm a shocking brute . I — I got carried away . Forget — forget the things I 've said of this girl . Forget ‘ em , will yer ?Starting to his feet .And look here ! A man who is n't a sportsman deserves to be shot . You 've won her ; I 've lost her . Congratulate yer , old chap ; congratulate yer !Pulling on his cap .Take care of her , that 's all ; m-m-mind you take care of her !

div.stage: He turns towards the door and she jumps up and runs to him and seizes his arm . FARNCOMBE also rises .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No , no , Nicko ! Nicko —!Giving FARNCOMBE a half frightened , half imploring look .Nicko , I can n't undo the mischief I 've done ; I can n't do that . But I can try to make it up to you — some of it — and I will , if you 'll let me .Putting her arms round his shoulders .Nicko ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Roughly .Make it — up to me ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Her face close to his .You know what I mean ! As soon as possible — next month , if you like — next week — quietly —!He grips her arms and stares at her blankly .Ha , ha ! Yes , you 've been in too great a hurry to settle matters , you have . Lord Farncombe and I — we — we 're not going to be married . I 've refused him .Wildly .I — I 've ruined you , Nicko ; but I — I 've told him — I 'm not going to draw him into my net !Clinging to JEYES and burying her face in the breast of his coat , crying .Oh ! Oh ! Oh ! I 'm not going to draw him into my net !

div.stage: Again there is a pause and then JEYES turns to FARNCOMBE , dazed .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Farncombe ——?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Inclining his head .Yes — yes ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: With feeling .My dear fellow , I — I ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Raising her head and speaking through her tears — to JEYES .Nicko , I — I want to have one more word with Lord Farncombe — just one more word .He nods understandingly and goes to the door on the left .
