She follows him .Only a minute ;he opens the doorand then you must walk away together , you and he , and part good friends .He goes out on to the landing and she closes the door and stands with her back to it , drying her eyes with her handkerchief . FARNCOMBE , still carrying his hat and overcoat , has crossed to the settee , a forlorn figure .W-w-well , you — you have had a lucky escape , have n't you ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Heavily .Escape ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Leaving the door and advancing .You — you 've heard what a cold-blooded , selfish wretch I am — how I 've treated Nicko !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Waving the idea away .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Coming to him .And you 've seen what I 'm like when I 'm in a rage ; you 've seen what the genuine Lily Margaret Upjohn is , without her disguise .Looking up into his face pathetically .Yes , that was me , Eddie , under the crust . Common as dirt , dear ; common as dirt !Holding the lapels of his coat .Oh ! Oh , you 'll always remember me , with my eyes starting out of my head , spitting at Nicko ! You 'll always picture that horrible sight when you think of me .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: You — you were provoked ; I — I admired you for it .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Tenderly .Ah , you dear boy !In an altered tone .Eddie ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Had you — a little hope — that , after all , I might turn your offer over in my mind and — and eventually ——?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Yes — yes .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With a catch in her breath .Ah ——!In a whisper .I — I 'll tell you something .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In his ear .I might have , if — if you 'd persisted .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Groaning .Oh-h-h-h !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Retreating a step or two .Thank God Nicko came along ! Thank God Nicko came along ! What was it his mother called us girls ? A menace to society ; creatures to be dreaded , and prayed against ! You see I was right in wishing to protect you for your mammy 's sake as well as your own . But , oh — thank God Nicko came along !He sits suddenly upon the settee and covers his face with his hands . She returns to him quickly .Ah , do n't do that ; do n't do that !Touching his hands .Eddie ! Eddie ! I 'm not worth it . Eddie !With an effort , he lifts his head .Listen . This is what I want to say to you . Do n't come near me any more ; you must n't . And do n't come to the theatre again either . If I thought you were sitting in front , I — I 'm sure I could n't ——!Entreatingly .Swear — swear you 'll keep away from me , and from the theatre !He nods .And you 'll never go to any supper or dinner or dance where you 're likely to meet the other girls , will you ? Eddie !He shakes his head .Swear !He rises and , as he does so , she grips the lapels of his coat again , her eyes blazing fiercely .Oh ! Oh ! If one of the other girls ever got hold of you , I — I —hissing into his faceI 'd kill her !She leaves him and goes to the door on the left and opens it .Nicko !JEYES enters the room .March , both of you !Exhausted .I — I 'm pretty well baked .FARNCOMBE joins LILY and JEYES at the door and she stands between the two men looking from one to the other and taking a hand of each .Ha , ha , ha ! I 've made the pair of you precious miserable , if you only knew it .To JEYES .The difference is that he 'll soon forget me , and you , with me for a wife , are doomed for life .Putting her hands upon JEYES ’ shoulders .Nicko ——!She kisses him lightly and , having done so , asks him a question with her eyes . JEYES turns aside and she faces FARNCOMBE and offers him her lips . They kiss .Good-bye .After a moment 's pause , to both of them .Away with you !The two men go out and she follows them to the top of the stairs and watches them descend . Then she slowly comes back into the room and stands listening at the door . There is a distant sound .Ah !Partly closing the door , she wanders about the room aimlessly for a while . Then , impulsively , she runs to the further window , lifts the sash , and looks below .Ah !... Ah !...Drawing back .Ah-h-h-h ——!

div.stage: She shuts the window and comes to the settee and , sitting there , takes off her shoes . Then she goes down upon the floor inelegantly , hunts for her slippers , and puts them on . As she rises , the door on the left is pushed open and MRS. UPJOHN peeps in cautiously .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: In a dressing-gown and with her hair , now very scanty , tightly screwed up .Lil ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Stiffening herself and speaking in a cold , level voice .Oh , I was just coming up to you , mother , to get you to undo me .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Bustling to LILY .I did n't mean to , but I fell off .Unhooking LILY 'S dress .It was the front-door I ‘ eard a minute ago , then ? It gave me sech a start .In difficulties with the hooks .Turn more to the light , dearie . These dressmakers do it a ’ purpose , I b'lieve . The ‘ ooks on that noo gown o ’ mine are a perfect myst'ry . Wot 's this ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Twisting her body .Oh , do n't fiddle so , mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: You did let ‘ im stay a time , Lil . ‘ Eaps to talk over , eh ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Stonily .Heaps .Trying to assist MRS. UPJOHN .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Well , dear ; well , well ! Tell me wot 's took place . Do n't keep me in suspense .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I sha n't tell you anything , mother , till I 've had a sleep . I must go through the sheets first .Stamping her foot .Oh , tear the thing ; tear it !

lg.l: ‘ Ave you consented to make ‘ im ‘ appy , poor young gentleman ? That 's all

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Thank you , mother .Slipping her arms out of her dress .I can manage the rest .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: But , Lil , dearie ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh , for mercy 's sake , leave me alone !Violently .Why can n't you leave me alone !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Ho ! Very good !Moving away indignantly as LILY , with shaking fingers , unfastens a necklace .This is my reward for layin ’ awake ‘ alf the night , is it , an ’ for thinkin ’ of you , an ’ wonderin ’ about you ! Ungrateful little puss , you !Going towards the door .After this , you can keep your affairs to yourself for as long as ever you choose . Do n't you expect me ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Suddenly , sitting upon the settee .Mother ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Sharply .Yes ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Her hand to her brow .Oh , mother ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Hurrying to LILY .Wot is it ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Swaying .At last — at last ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: At last ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Clinging to MRS. UPJOHN .I 'm in love , mother — I 'm in love — in love — in love ——!

div.stage: END OF THE THIRD ACT .

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT

stage.stage: The scene is the same as in the preceding act , but the light outside is brighter and warmer and in the room is more diffused . On the table in the centre , placed close to the settee , there is a small tray with a breakfast of tea and toast upon it . The bedroom door is partly open .

[ LILY , wan and red-eyed , is lying , propped up by cushions , upon the settee . A newspaper is on her lap but she is gazing at vacancy . She is in négligé . A dainty morning-robe covers her night-gown , her bare feet are in slippers , and her hair is in a simple knot . MAUD is at one of the drawers of the cupboard at the back , engaged in selecting some articles of lingerie , and MRS. UPJOHN , completely dressed for the day , is sitting in the arm-chair by the centre table , her face hidden by a newspaper which she is reading . Presently MAUD shuts the drawer and , carrying the lingerie , comes forward .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: To LILY .What frock 'll you put on ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Starting slightly .Eh ?

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: One of your embroidered muslins , or your Ninon ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Languidly .Either ; I do n't care .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: Oh , gracious , what on earth is the matter with you this morning ! I 've never known you as queer as this after any hop you 've been to in my time .To MRS. UPJOHN , who has lowered her paper .Nothing wrong , is there ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Turning over and burying her head in the cushions .Maud .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: Moving to the settee and bending over LILY .Here I am , lovey .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a muffled voice .Go into the next room and shut the door , and do n't let me see your stupid , fat face till I come to you .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: Laughing heartily .Ha , ha , ha ! Ho , ho , ho ! That 's better .Going to the bedroom door .That 's how I like to hear her talk . We need n't send for Dr. Gilson yet awhile . Ha , ha , ha !

div.stage: She disappears into the bedroom and closes the door .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Looking at LILY .Lil .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Yes , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ Ave another cup o ’ tea , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ Nother bit o ’ toast , then ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Smoke a cigarette .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: You always do ‘ ave a w'iff after your breakfast . Come !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Rising and walking away .Oh , dear ; oh , dear ! Deuce take Carlton Smythe an ’ ‘ is supper party — those are my sentiments ; an ’ Lal Roper , busybody that ‘ e is ! Things were goin ’ on with us as smooth an ’ peaceful as could be , before this upset .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Raising herself , angrily .You were in it , mother ; you 're as much to blame as anybody .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Halting .‘ Ow in it ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In Uncle Lal 's artful plan to prevent Nicko from being invited . You 've confessed you were .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Lal twisted me round ‘ is little finger . I was clay in the porter 's ‘ and , as your dad was fond of sayin ’ .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Changing her position .If only Nicko had been there , I should n't have given young Farncombe all those dances , nor wandered about with him in the intervals , nor allowed him to see me home . It all simply would n't , could n't have happened .Hitting a cushion .Oh !Sitting up and embracing her knees .Mother ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Behind the settee .Wot ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Knitting her brows .I — I 'm so surprised at myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Surprised ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: So — so disappointed with myself .

lg.l: Why , you ‘ ave n't done anything that — that 's not quite respectable ,

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No , I have n't done anything that 's actually not nice , but — fancy !——

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Close to LILY .Fancy ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Opening her eyes widely .Fancy my letting myself go with young Farncombe as I did ! He — he 'd been admiring me from a distance for weeks and weeks , but I 'd scarcely noticed him till last night !Leaning her head against MRS. UPJOHN , softly .I — I always thought I was such a cold girl , mother , in — in that way .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: I s'pose it was wot 's called love at first sight , Lil .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Laughing shamefacedly .Ha , ha , ha !Putting her feet to the ground and shielding her face with her hands .Oh , do n't talk rot , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Moving away .Any'ow , it 's not too late , Lil — even now ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Not too late ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Behind the centre table .To back out , dearie . The Captain could n't possibly ‘ old you to a ‘ asty promise given ‘ im between four an ’ five in the mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh ! Oh , how can you ! I 've passed my word to Nicko and I would n't break it for twenty thousand pounds .Looking up .Mother ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Fussing with the things upon the table .Yes ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Resolutely .I 'm going to pull Nicko up , mother . I 've dragged him down , and I mean to raise him .Clenching her hands .So help me God , I do !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Well , you 've got a tough job before you , Lil , in my opinion .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Perhaps ; but I mean to succeed .After a pause .Besides ——

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Besides ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Slowly .I 've told you — Nicko or no Nicko — I 'm determined — I 'm determined not to draw Eddie Farncombe into my net .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Into your net ?Another pause .Lil ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: That 's twice you 've made use o ’ that remark . ‘ Oo 's accused you ——?There is a lively rat-tat at the door on the left .Come in !

div.stage: The door opens and JIMMIE BIRCH bounces into the room .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: As she closes the door .Ah , Ma ! Ah , Lillums !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Good mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Kissing MRS. UPJOHN .Ha , ha ! We 've met before , this morning , have n't we !Coming to LILY .Well , dear old girl , and how are you to-day ?Kissing LILY and then eyeing her keenly .A wreck ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rather .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: I ought to be , but I 'm not . Directly I laid my pretty head on my pillow I went off , and never stirred till I found the breakfast-tray on my chest .Reckoning on her fingers .Five to six — six to seven — seven to eight — eight to nine — nine to ten — ten to eleven . I 've had six hours ; that 's not so dusty .To LILY , slyly .You did n't sleep very soundly , probably ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Not very .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Smiling from ear to ear .Excited ?LILY shrugs her shoulders . There is a silence and then JIMMIE , still beaming , looks round and sees that MRS. UPJOHN has seated herself upon the fauteuil-stool .May I sit down for a minute ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Of course , Jimmie ; do .

div.stage: JIMMIE sits in the arm-chair by the centre table , awaiting some communication which does n't come . MRS. UPJOHN drums upon the table with her fingers and LILY busies herself with re-arranging the cushions on the settee .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: After a while .Hope I have n't dropped in too early ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Settling her shoulders into the cushions .Not a bit , dear .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: It 's nearly half-past twelve . I — I dashed round .After another pause , unable to restrain herself further .Any news ? Any-any-anything to tell me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Abruptly .Yes .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: W-w-what ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Lil 's engaged .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Hah !Triumphantly .Hah , hah !Clapping her hands and beating her feet upon the floor .Hah , hah , hah , hah !Jumping up and sitting beside LILY and hugging and kissing her .Oh ! Oh ! Oh ! Y 'm ! Y 'm ! Y 'm ! Oh , you humbugs !Rising and rushing at MRS. UPJOHN and embracing her .You solemn humbug , Ma !Leaving MRS. UPJOHN and singing and dancing to the refrain sung in the previous Act .“ If you would only , only love me ;— ” Ha , ha , ha ! “ If you would merely , merely say ,—— ”Her voice gradually dying away as she sees that the expression on LILY 'S face , and upon MRS. UPJOHN 'S , does n't alter .“ Wait but a little —standing stilllittle — for me —— ”

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Caustically .Yes , you ‘ ad better wait a little ; you 'd better wait till you ‘ ear ‘ oo she 's engaged to .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Who — to !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Studying her nails .Whom to , mother .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Why , is n't it ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: No , it ai n't . It 's the Captain .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: T-t-the Cap —!To LILY .N-n-nicko ?LILY nods . JIMMIE draws a deep breath .Oh-h-h-h !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Calmly .Nicko turned up here early this morning — while Eddie — while Lord Farncombe was with me , in fact — and I — we — the three of us — we talked matters over , and — and ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Her eyes starting out of her head .Was there a row ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh , do n't be so curious , Jimmie . Poor Nicko has been after me for six years . A girl must play the game , if she 's at all decent and wishes to preserve a shred of self-respect .

div.stage: Again there is a pause and then JIMMIE silently resumes her seat in the arm-chair .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Moistening her lips with her tongue — to JIMMIE .‘ Ow do you feel about it ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Thoughtfully .How do I feel about it ?To LILY .May I say ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Coldly .Certainly .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Rubbing the arm of her chair with the palm of her hand .Well , if I were on board a ship at this moment , I should be ringing for the stewardess ; that 's how I feel about it .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Throwing herself , face downward , at full length upon the settee .Oh ! Oh , you 're just like the rest of our girls on the question of marriage ! You — you — you 're detestable !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Sliding out of her chair and kneeling at the settee and putting an arm round LILY .Oh , Lil — Lil ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Repulsing her .Yes , you are !Raising herself upon her elbow .You 'd rejoice to see me draw this boy into my net , would n't you ! You know you would .MRS. UPJOHN rises and comes forward .I dare say you jolly well would n't object to catching him yourself if you 'd half a chance !Fiercely .You try it ; you try it — you , or any of you !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Attempting to rise , scandalised .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Holding her .No , no ——! Jimmie ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Lil , I 'm perfec'ly ashamed of you , speakin ’ to Jimmie Birch in that manner .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Dropping her head on JIMMIE 'S shoulder .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: She does n't mean it .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: I ‘ ope not . It ai n't exac'ly pleasant to ‘ ave a dog in the manger for a daughter .To LILY .Why should n't young Farncombe turn ‘ is attention to Miss Birch , pray , or to any young lady who does n't object to take your leavin 's !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To MRS. UPJOHN .H'sh , h'sh , h'sh !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Walking about .No , I wo n't ‘ ush !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To LILY , quietly .I 'll come back in the afternoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Lil seems to ‘ ave got some maggot or other in ‘ er brain about drawin ’ Lord Farncombe into ‘ er net . Net indeed !JIMMIE , not heeding MRS. UPJOHN , arranges LILY comfortably upon the settee and then rises and smoothes out her skirt preparatory to departure .As Lal Roper was sayin ’ yesterday , our tiptop , aristocratic English fam'lies ought to be ‘ xtremely grateful that strong , ‘ ealthy perfeshunals o ’ the class of Miss ‘ Arker an ’ Miss Trevail an ’ Miss Shafto are enterin ’ their ranks . An ’ if Lil chooses to be pig - ‘ eaded enough ——!JIMMIE makes a movement towards MRS. UPJOHN .‘ Ave a bottle o ’ ginger beer before you go .There is a prolonged , playful knocking at the door on the left followed , on the part of those in the room , by a gloomy pause .That is Lal .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Groaning .Oh-h-h-h !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Drawing a long face .H 'm !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To JIMMIE .Oh , Jimmie — stay ——!

div.stage: The knocking is repeated . JIMMIE retreats to the right as MRS. UPJOHN goes to the door and opens it . ROPER is outside .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Entering , in high spirits .Hullo , hullo , hullo , hul-lo !Embracing MRS. UPJOHN .Morning , Ma !Advancing .Any more bids for the handsome gilt candelabra with the crystal drops ? Ha , ha , ha !To JIMMIE .Morning , Jimmie !Looking down , upon LILY , eagerly .Well , Lil ! Well , my pet !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a weary tone , giving him the tips of her fingers and then turning upon her side with her face to the back of the settee .How are you , Uncle Lal ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Chilled .Oh , I — thank you , Lil —After a short pause , to MRS. UPJOHN — glancing at LILY .Not up to much to-day ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Glumly .No great shakes .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Dancing too hard , I ‘ spect .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: A deal too ‘ ard .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: After another pause .Anything else amiss , Ma ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Sitting upon the box-ottoman — to JIMMIE , who is at the piano examining some of the music .You tell Lal , Jimmie .

lg.stage: To JIMMIE , who comes to the settee — apprehensively .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Behind the settee , gravely .No , the old Pandora is n't going to score this time , Lal .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Is n't going to —? I d-d-do n't follow you .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Be plain , Jimmie .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Endeavouring to relieve the situation .Ha , ha ! Nature 's taken precious good care of that , in my case .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Angrily .Now , look here , Jimmie ! A jest is a capital thing in its way . No man has a keener sense of humour than Lal Roper . But there are occasions when it 's out o ’ place , and this is one of ‘ em , my dear ; and if it 's not putting you to serious inconvenience ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Also losing her temper .Oh , well , then , have it in the neck ! Lil 's declined young Farncombe . There ! And when you crack a joke next , Mr. Roper , I beg you 'll contrive to favour us with a little variety ;flouncing awaybecause you bore me pallid with your rotten wheezes , and always have done .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Going to MRS. UPJOHN , aghast at the tidings .Ma ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: To ROPER , under her breath .Wo n't draw ‘ im into ‘ er net , Uncle .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Wo n't draw him into her ——?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: At the back .K-n-e-double t — net !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Pacifically .Jimmie ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Mimicking ROPER derisively .Hullo , hullo , hullo , hul-lo ! Fresh fish from the sea ! Buy ‘ em on the beach ; buy ‘ em on the beach ; buy ‘ em on the beach !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To JIMMIE , indignantly .Jimmie Birch ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Sitting upon the fauteuil-stool .Ha , ha !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To MRS. UPJOHN , wiping his brow .Of course , there is this to be said , Ma .Rallying at the idea .It may be wise of dear Lil to decline Farncombe at first . It — it — it — it does n't do for a girl , does it , to appear to throw herself at any man , let alone a young fellow of the position — the — the — the social status ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Suddenly sitting up and putting her feet to the floor again .Oh , for mercy 's sake , cease discussing my affairs in my presence !To MRS. UPJOHN .Mother , why do you keep Uncle Lal in the dark ?To JIMMIE .Jimmie , why do n't you ——?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: In the dark !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Yes , Lal ; your flyin ’ out at Jimmie over ‘ er ‘ armless joke stopped ‘ er finishin ’ .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Finishing ——?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Lil 's not on'y refused young Farncombe but she 's gone an ’ plighted ‘ erself to another individual .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Plighted herself ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Passionately .To one of the best ! To one of the best !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Stupefied .Do I — do I know him ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Ha !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Know him ! You know him sufficiently to have plotted and schemed to prevent his being asked to the party last night .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To LILY .Did Lal do that ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Did he !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Impudence !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Sitting in the arm-chair by the centre table — quietly .Jeyes !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Nicko .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Firmly .Nicko .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: But the Captain was at the party last night notwithstandin ’ .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To MRS. UPJOHN .Nonsense , Ma !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Yes , Nicko managed to get into the theatre somehow or other .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To LILY .And watched you and young Farncombe ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: And stationed himself under the portico of Twenty seven , to see who brought me home .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Oh ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ E 's always been frightfully jealous , the Captain ‘ as .

lg.l: Oh , so really it 's entirely owing to Lal
Roper 's interference that matters were brought to a head this morning !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Her eyes flashing .Entirely .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Joining in the attack upon ROPER .Yes , if Lal ‘ ad been content to mind ‘ is own business ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: And had n't meddled ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: An ’ muddled ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Things might have gone on much the same as before .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: An ’ might ‘ ave ended different .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rising and walking away to the right .Ah , no , mother ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Rising and joining LILY .Certainly they might .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Rising .Any'ow I ‘ ope it 'll be a lesson to Lal ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Do you , Ma !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Moving over to the girls .Not to put ‘ is fingers into other people 's pies .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To MRS. UPJOHN , with a withering glance at ROPER .Oh , you are sanguine !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Rising and straightening himself out .Ma — Mrs. Upjohn — Lily ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Scornfully .Hullo , hullo , hullo , hul-lo ——!

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To JIMMIE .P'sh !Impressively .Ma — Lily — for years — longer than it 's agreeable to count — I 've been a patron of the drama — particularly musical comedy , of which I 've studied the development with especial interest .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Resting her elbows upon the back of the settee .Yes , you 've studied a lot of development , Lal , in your day .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Ignoring JIMMIE .It 's been a fad with me ; I put it no higher than that .Producing his gloves .But I 've devoted time to it ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Any amount .

lg.l: Often to the neglect of my ventures in the
City . Here I am now , for instance .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: That 's obvious .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: And — I frankly admit it — I 've had more than one serious dispute with Mrs. Roper on the subject .JIMMIE softly whistles a few bars of “ Rule , Britannia . ”Yesterday , by a coincidence —feeling the outside of his breast-pocketletter from the wife — full o ’ complaints — have n't been to Bexhill , to her and the kids , for weeks . And to do Ellen Roper justice , she 's not the woman to grumble without cause .Picking up his hat and cane which he has placed upon the centre table .Dash it all , home ties are home ties !Polishing his hat with his sleeve .And , taking one consideration with another — and after this — this occurrence — it 's my intention for the future — my firm intention ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Running to ROPER and throwing her arms around his neck .Oh , Uncle Lal , not altogether ! We 're tired and cross this morning ! Not altogether !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Behind the centre table .No , no , Uncle , you must n't ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To ROPER .Forgive us !Coaxingly .Mother and Jimmie are cats ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN AND JIMMIE
sp.p: Oh ——!

div.stage: The door on the left opens , and GLADYS enters with a card on a salver .

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: Advancing to LILY .Are you in ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In ?

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: Surveying LILY with mingled disdain and pity .Oh you do look washed out !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Going to GLADYS .Never you mind whether I look washed out or not . Who is it ?

div.stage: LILY takes the card , reads some writing upon it , and stands twiddling the card in her fingers .

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: They 're in the dining-room .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To GLADYS , after a pause .W-wait outside — on the landing .

sp.speaker: GLADYS
sp.p: Oh , all right . This wo n't get my silver cleaned .

div.stage: GLADYS withdraws . LILY waits for the door to close and then walks about distractedly .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh , why can n't they leave me alone ! What do they want with me now , both of them !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Moving towards LILY .‘ Oo ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Nicko 's downstairs — with Lord Farncombe .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Lord Farncombe ——!

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: And Jeyes !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Reading the card again .Nicko asks me to see him and the boy together .ROPER and MRS. UPJOHN go to LILY , one on each side of her , and try to read the card . She pushes them from her and sits in the arm-chair by the centre table .I wo n't ; I wo n't .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Joining MRS. UPJOHN and ROPER .Yes , yes , Lil ; do .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Bewildered .Wot ——?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Perhaps they 've arrived at a friendly understanding ——!

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Understanding ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Excitedly .And have come to propose that Lil should choose between them !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Great Scot ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I have chosen ; I have chosen . It 's settled .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Undoubtedly she ought to see them .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: It 's a shame to persecute me so — a shame !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE , MRS. UPJOHN , AND ROPER
sp.p: Behind LILY 'S chair .Lil ! Lily ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Give ‘ em a minute , dear .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Hear what they 've got to say .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: It would be uncivil not to .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Oh —! Oh ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE . }
sp.p: Buck up , Lil ! }

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN . }
sp.p: ‘ Ark to reason , dearie . }

sp.speaker: JIMMIE , MRS. UPJOHN , AND ROPER
sp.p: Lil ! Lily ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Yielding helplessly .Oh , very well ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE , MRS. UPJOHN , AND ROPER
sp.p: Ah ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Tell Gladys — when I ring ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Flying to the door on the left .I 'll tell her .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To MRS. UPJOHN , importantly .Lucky I was on the spot ; lucky I was on the spot .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: On the landing , to GLADYS .Bring the gentlemen up when Miss Lily rings .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rising and pacing the room on the right .Give me some stockings !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Returning and closing the door and then whispering to ROPER .Bet my boots that 's it !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: To JIMMIE , in a whisper .Choose between ‘ em !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: What else can it be ?

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: I can n't ——

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Throwing herself into ROPER 'S arms .Oh , if it is !

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Hugging her .Oh ——!

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Suddenly , releasing herself .Oh ——!Haughtily .Thought you were Lily .

div.stage: MRS. UPJOHN returns , carrying a pair of stockings . LILY seats herself upon the fauteuil-stool where , concealed by the centre table , she draws on the stockings with MRS. UPJOHN 'S assistance .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Whimpering .Oh —! Oh ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Do n't , dearie ; do n't . Mother 's ‘ ere .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: Impatiently .I — ah — I think I 'll run downstairs and shake hands with Jeyes and Farncombe while Lily 's tidying herself .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Who has moved over to the right — to ROPER .Be careful . I should advise you not to risk it .

sp.speaker: ROPER
sp.p: At the door .Risk it ?

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: If Nicko knows you were the cause of his being shut out of the party last night , he 'll simply throttle you .

div.stage: He disappears , closing the door , as MAUD enters from the bedroom with a pair of shoes .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Weakly .Oh ! Oh ! Oh ! Get me something to keep these up with .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To MAUD .Ribbon ——

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Snatching the shoes from MAUD .Ribbon .

div.stage: MAUD opens one of the drawers underneath the further cupboard on the left and finds a roll of bright , new ribbon , while JIMMIE , searching among the objects on the centre table , discovers the case of manicure instruments and takes from it a pair of scissors .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Putting on her shoes — to MRS. UPJOHN .No , no ; that 's the left foot — oh ——!

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Do n't agitate yourself , dearie . Mother 's ‘ ere .

div.stage: MAUD comes to the centre table with the ribbon and JIMMIE cuts off two lengths from the roll .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: To JIMMIE .Morning , Miss Jimmie !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To MAUD .Morning !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To MRS. UPJOHN .Where 's the mirror ? Where 's the mirror ?

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Taking the mirror from the table and giving it to LILY .‘ Ere it is , dearie ; ‘ ere it is . An ’ I 'm ‘ ere too .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Viewing herself in the mirror and running her hand over her hair .Oh , how horrid I look !JIMMIE goes to LILY with the two lengths of ribbon and MAUD replaces the roll in the drawer .Ring the bell .JIMMIE hands LILY the garters , relieving her of the mirror , and MRS. UPJOHN hastens to the fireplace and presses the bell-push continuously .That 'll do , Maud ; you hook it .

sp.speaker: MAUD
sp.p: Going to the bedroom door .Ha , ha , ha ! Ho , ho , ho ! That 's how I like to hear her talk . Ha , ha , ha , ha !

div.stage: MAUD vanishes into the bedroom , closing the door , and LILY , having tied up her stockings , rises and comes to the settee .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Still pressing the bell-push .Now I do n't believe I 've rung .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: At the uttermost tension .Ah , stop it , mother ; stop it !Sitting on the settee .We 're not calling the fire-brigade .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: At the back of the settee , to LILY .I 'll wait in your bedroom till the men have been shown up , and sneak out that way .Bending over LILY .Mind ! If Nicko is willing , after all , that you should make your choice ——

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Advancing .Yes , dearie , if ‘ e is willing ——

lg.l: I tell you I have made it . I keep on telling you
I 've chosen — I 've chosen — I 've chosen !
If you torment me any more , either of you ——!

div.stage: MRS. UPJOHN and JIMMIE retreat precipitately to the bedroom door . They open the door and then , standing in the doorway , listen intently .

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: Disappearing .Ah ——!

lg.stage: Only her head visible , speaking to LILY in a hoarse whisper .

div.stage: The head is withdrawn and the door softly closed . After a pause , GLADYS enters at the other door followed by JEYES and FARNCOMBE . The men are carrying their hats and canes . GLADYS retires , closing the door , and JEYES comes to LILY and shakes hands with her .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: To LILY , gently .How are you to-day , Lil ? Very fagged ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Almost inaudibly .I am a little .JEYES turns from her , to lay his hat and cane upon the box-ottoman , and then FARNCOMBE , who has hung back , advances hesitatingly to the further side of the centre table and bows to LILY . She rises and , avoiding his eyes , gives him a limp hand across the table .How d'ye do ?To JEYES who , having got rid of his hat and cane , moves away from the ottoman .Sit down , wo n't you ?She resumes her seat upon the settee and JEYES , with a nod , sits in the arm-chair by the centre table . FARNCOMBE remains standing and again she addresses him without meeting his eyes .And you ?

div.stage: FARNCOMBE , with another bow , sits upon the fauteuil-stool . There is a brief silence and then JEYES speaks .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Lil ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Y-yes ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: In the first place , Farncombe wants you distinctly to understand how it is he 's committing this breach of his compact with you .To FARNCOMBE .You promised ——?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I promised never to attempt to come near Miss Parradell again , nor even to enter the theatre .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: To LILY .And if I 'm any judge of a man , Lily , Farncombe would have kept his promise . He 'd have kept it faithfully , but for me . I 've brought him along — insisted on it .Emphatically .I 've brought him along . See ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: W-w-why , Nicko ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I 'll tell you , my dear . You remember , when we left you early this morning , ordering us to walk away together and to part good friends ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: P-perfectly .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Well , we did walk away together , and we did part good friends . But we did n't part at all till some hours later , in his rooms . We did n't part till I 'd made him stand by me and listen to me while I had a long jaw with my brother on the ‘ phone .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Wonderingly .With — your ——?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: About that Rhodesian business .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: What Rhodesian business ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: I mentioned it to you yesterday . Bob owns a third , with Peter Chalmers and Tom Dalby , of a group of farms near Bulawayo , and he 's been badgering me eternally to cut this and to settle out there as their agent .Simply .And I 've accepted , old girl .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With a blank face .Ac-cepted ?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Grimly .Leaving you to bring an action against me , to recover damages for a broken heart .Drawing a deep breath .Yes , I 'm chucking you , Lil . I give you formal notice of my intention ; and you can drive down to your solicitors this afternoon and instruct them to writ me without delay .Forcing a laugh .Ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Faintly .Nicko ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Unless — unless you 've an idea of consoling yourself shortly with — with another chap , and prefer not to carry the matter into Court .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: About to rise .Nicko ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Restraining her by a gesture .H'sh ! No , no , no .She sinks back .Ah , Lil — Lil — I know you 're full of generous , honest impulses , though I did tear you to rags in Farncombe 's hearing a few hours ago . But I 'm not going to allow you to sacrifice yourself to them ; I — I — I 've come to my senses , and I 'm not going to permit it .Bending forward .Oh , my dear , why should I make you pay for the weaknesses of my character ? Because that 's what it ‘ ud amount to . I 've bullied you for having played skittles with my life , my career . So you have ! Damn it , so you have ! But you 've done it out of blind thoughtlessness ; and if I 'd been a fairly strong man , with some ballast in me , you could n't have landed me where I am — not you nor fifty Pandora girls !Sitting erect .And that — that 's the moral of the tale ; and — and —abruptly , to FARNCOMBEThere 's nothing more , is there , Farncombe ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Brokenly .Except that — that I 'd like to repeat — what I 've already said to Jeyes — that I —his elbows on the table , his head bowedoh , you make me feel terribly small , Jeyes .

div.stage: Again there is a pause , and then LILY struggles to her feet and holds out her hand to JEYES uncertainly , and at once he rises and takes her in his arms . FARNCOMBE also rises and , standing behind the settee , turns his back to JEYES and LILY .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To JEYES , choking .Ah , Nicko — I can n't — I can n't ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Patting her shoulder .Ah ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Why , what — what would become of my resolutions ——?

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Resolutions ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To — to raise you up , Nicko .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: You are raising me up — setting me on my legs again .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: In a fright .And — and drawing Eddie into my net !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Oh , we 've talked of that too , he and I . He 's given me an account of what passed between you here . My dear girl , your conscience may be quite clear on that point . Nobody can ever reproach you with trying to draw him into your net .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: They would — they would ——

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: At all events , the task you have to face now is to prove to the world — his world — that Miss Parradell is equal to playing “ lead ” on a bigger stage than the stage of the Pandora .Holding her at arms ’ length and shaking her fondly .And you 'll do it ! Ho , ho , ho , ho ! You 'll do it ! Ha , ha , ha —!His voice dies away miserably and he releases her . Then , pulling himself together , he looks at his watch .Well , I 've got to lunch with Bob at half-past one at the Junior Carlton ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Agitatedly .Ah , it 's not nearly that , Nicko ; it 's not nearly that ! Nicko —!She passes him , moving towards the door on the left as if to intercept him , and then turns to him . A strip of ribbon lies upon the spot where she has been standing . After gazing at it for a moment , he stoops and picks it up .Oh —!He folds the ribbon carefully and puts it into his pocket .Oh —!Hitching up her stocking through her robe , piteously .Ha , ha !

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha ——!

div.stage: They face one another , laughing , and then she sits upon the fauteuil-stool and drops her head upon the table and he fetches his hat and cane from the box-ottoman .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Weeping .Nicko — Nicko ——!

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Coming to her .Oh , this is n't good-bye , Lil , not by any manner o ’ means , my dear . We 'll kill the fatted calf several times before I start — you , I , and the boy . Besides , by-and-by , you and he must take a trip and come out to see me . “ Seringa Vale ” is the farm where I shall be quartered , Bob tells me .Looking into space .Jermyn Street to Seringa Vale !Shaking himself .Ph'h , there are no great distances in these days !To FARNCOMBE , with a change of tone .Farncombe —FARNCOMBE comes forward .You dine with me to-night , recollect ; it 's an engagement .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Eight o'clock .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Eight o'clock .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: Catani 's .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Catani 's .

div.stage: Without looking at LILY again , JEYES goes to the door and opens it . FARNCOMBE follows him and the two men halt in the doorway .

sp.speaker: JEYES
sp.p: To FARNCOMBE , with a motion of his head towards LILY .And afterwards — you fetch her from the theatre and take her home . That 's your job .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Rising .Oh ——!

div.stage: FARNCOMBE goes out on to the landing with JEYES and parts from him at the top of the stairs . Then FARNCOMBE slowly returns , closes the door , and finds LILY sitting upon the settee in a woeful attitude .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Coming to LILY and standing before her , thoughtfully .Lily ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Feebly .Eh — eh ——?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: I 'm afraid there 's one thing finer than winning the woman you love and , when you 've won her , being prepared to go through fire and water for her .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Having the courage to give her up , as Jeyes has done .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: With a renewed outburst .Oh , Nicko ! Poor Nicko ! Poor Nicko !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Sitting beside her and taking her hand consolingly .By George , he 's a brick , is n't he !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: After a pause , drying her eyes .Eddie ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: If — if ever we marry ——

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: His jaw falling .If ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: W-w-when , then . When we marry , you 'll be obliged to resign your commission in the Guards , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Snapping his fingers .P'sh ! I sha n't care a rap about that .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Snatching her hand away .The snobs ! The snobs ! They 'd let you marry any bit of trash in your own set ; but a Pandora girl , though she 's as pure as the Queen of England ——! Oh , the contemptible snobs !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Regaining possession of her hand .H'sh ! H'sh ! It — it 's the practice ——

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Blow the practice ! A cheerful reflection for me , it 'll be . The arrant snobs !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Stroking her hand .Ah ! Ah !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: And then — poor mother ! You — you wo n't be very proud of poor mother .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Your mother ?Boyishly .Oh , she — she 's an awfully good sort .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: She has n't an H. to her name .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Inadvertently .She ought n't to have .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Withdrawing her hand again , sharply .She calls herself Hupjohn , you mean !

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Distressed .No , no , no .In a difficulty .Er — at any rate , h 's do n't lead you to heaven , do they ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Gloomily .You 're right ; mother 's lead her to ‘ eaven .Rising and walking away .Well , you 'd better go now .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Rising .And to-night ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No ; I 'll come home alone .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Lily ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Imperatively .Please ——!

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: When ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Moving to the door on the left .Not for two or three days . Give me time to shake down over this .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Taking up his hat and cane which he has left upon the centre table .Sunday ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Fretfully .No .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Monday ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Opening the door .No .

sp.speaker: FARNCOMBE
sp.p: Joining her at the door .Tuesday ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Appealingly .I — I 'll write .Again he takes her hand , she keeping him at a distance . He attempts to lessen the distance , but she checks him , shaking her head .Not just yet , Eddie .He smiles at her tenderly and , with a bow , departs . From the doorway , she watches him disappear ; then she shuts the door and wanders listlessly to the door of the bedroom . Her hand lingers upon the knob for a moment , and then she opens the door a little way and calls .Mother ! Mother ——!

div.stage: She leaves the door and is returning to the settee when MRS. UPJOHN enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: All agog .Yes , Lil ?LILY seats herself upon the settee without speaking .Yes , dearie ; yes ?Advancing to the centre table .‘ Ave they given you your choice ?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Dully .No ; they 've given me no choice .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Advancing further .Wot ——?

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Nicko 's going out to South Africa , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: South Africa !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Well , to Rhodesia .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Then you 're free , Lil !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: No , I 'm not .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Not !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Nicko — Nicko 's handed me over , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ Anded you over !

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: To — to Lord Farncombe .

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Gasping .An ’ you an ’ the young gentleman ——!

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: I — I suppose so .

lg.stage: Sinking into the arm chair by the centre table .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: Transferring herself from the settee to MRS. UPJOHN 'S lap .Oh ! Oh ! Oh !Putting her arms round MRS. UPJOHN 'S neck .Oh , poor Nicko !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Soothingly .‘ E 'll ‘ ave ‘ is reward , Lil ; ‘ e 'll ‘ ave ‘ is reward ‘ ereafter .

sp.speaker: LILY
sp.p: And poor Carlton Smythe ! Oh , poor Carlton !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: Poor Carlton ——?

lg.l: He 's losing every one of his best girls , mother . Gwennie Harker —
Maidie Trevail — Eva Shafto — and now me ! Oh , poor Carlton !

sp.speaker: MRS. UPJOHN
sp.p: ‘ Ush , dearie ; ‘ ush ! Do n't consider ‘ im !Rocking LILY to and fro like a baby .Think — think wot a lot o ’ good you 're all doin ’ to the aristocracy !

div.stage: The door on the left opens and JIMMIE and ROPER look in gleefully and then tiptoe towards LILY and MRS. UPJOHN .
